campaign.story:
As seen on:
Visit our website at https://www.HollywoodSciFi.org
Our Twitter is https://twitter.com/hollywoodscifi
Our Facebook is https://www.facebook.com/hollywoodscifi
New Starship Foundation, the nonprofit behind the
Enterprise-D Bridge Restoration, with board members including the greatest talents in science fiction, presents THE HOLLYWOOD SCIENCE FICTION MUSEUM. This will be the first museum in the world to exclusively show the history of sci-fi films, TV, art and literature through props, sets and costumes, as well as show advancements in space travel and teach Real Science through Science Fiction. It will be an interactive museum with fully immersive environments and touch screens that will incorporate old and new footage from actors, filmmakers and NASA astronauts and scientists, and will present both the fact and fiction of sci-fi. This will eventually teach Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) based education in a fun new way to all ages. The museum will include exhibits from: Star Trek, Star Wars, Doctor Who, 2001, Alien, Metropolis, Thunderbirds, Firefly, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica, Stargate, Blake's 7, Ghostbusters, Farscape, The Time Machine, Godzilla, X-Men, Avengers, Superman, Planet of the Apes, Back to the Future, Day the Earth Stood Still, V, Batman, Six Million Dollar Man, Bionic Woman, Flash Gordon, Buck Rogers, as well as Fantasy like Lord of the Rings, Labyrinth, Legend, Munsters, Herbie the Love Bug, Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, Dark Crystal, Game of Thrones, Anime like Akira and Speed Racer, and anything else we can fit within our walls.
This Kickstarter is to acquire the funds to develop our 2015 Hollywood Sci Fi Museum, which will be smaller than the future museum, but still significant and unique. This "concept art" of the giant Millennium Falcon and Enterprise-D is for our 2018 Hollywood Sci Fi Museum.
Helping to develop the museum is http://rhetroactive.com/ the creative design firm that was part of the original team behind Star Trek: The Experience at the Las Vegas Hilton, the Despicable Me and Simpson's Springfield attractions at Universal Studios, and The Grammy Museum. Other supporters of New Starship Foundation include Paramount, Gersh, Google, Bentley Systems and Entertainment Earth, as well as numerous Star Trek actors and numerous celebrities who wanted to take a photo in our Enterprise-D Captain's Chair.
Mission Statement: The mission of New Starship Foundation and the Hollywood Science Fiction Museum is to inspire people of all ages and nationalities with an uplifting vision of the future found in science fiction media, art and literature by teaching Real Science through Science Fiction, including technology, ecology, engineering, computers, robotics, math, medicine, space travel and all aspects of filmmaking through fun, interactive exhibits and programs.
In addition to displays for: Star Trek, Star Wars, Doctor Who, Firefly, Farscape, Stargate and Battlestar Galactica, featured rooms will include:
HALL OF SPACESHIPS
Large scale interactive models of sci-fi ships.
HALL OF ROBOTS  
Famous TV and Film Sci-Fi Robots that will be interactive.
HALL OF REAL ROBOTS  
A rotating interactive exhibit of the most advanced real robots in the world.
HALL OF CARS  
Sci-fi and futuristic cars you can climb inside and learn about, hosted by the people who created them and actors who drove them.
THE ART OF SPECIAL EFFECTS and ANIMATION
A room filled with prosthetics, masks, makeup and animatronic props from the greatest makeup and specific effects artists, with videos and interactive displays.This will also include the art of Stop Motion Animation with props and models by Ray Harryhausen, George Pal and Willis O'Brien.
In the same building will be the Starship Restaurant, Gift Shop and a room for rotating exhibits and displays for upcoming films and TV shows.
This Kickstarter is to obtain the initial funds to develop our 2015 Hollywood Science Fiction Museum. It will help us create the materials needed as well as hire experts in finances to contact large investors and corporate donors, as well as government grants, sponsorship and branding.
Phase One: 2014-2015 Develop and secure all aspects of the 2015 Hollywood Sci-Fi Museum, complete our Enterprise-D and Original Series Bridge sets
Phase Two: 2015 Testing, Preview and Grand Opening of the Hollywood Sci-Fi Museum
Phase Three: 2015-2018 Continue to expand and improve museum;  rotate exhibits, hold premieres, weddings and special events; prove that a sci-fi museum in Hollywood can be sustainable; continue to raise funds to develop the permanent 2018 museum
Phase Four: Tentatively 2018 Unveil our permanent Hollywood Science Fiction Museum
The New Starship Foundation began when writer and fan Huston Huddleston rescued the touring sets of the Enterprise-D Bridge from Star Trek: The Next Generation and the Captain Kirk's Original Series Bridge from the original Star Trek, which had been left outside for over 5 years. Both were created by Paramount in 1998, with some pieces from Star Trek: The Experience from the Las Vegas Hilton. In 2012, through Kickstarter and Indiegogo, we raised roughly 1/4 of the money we needed to restore our Enterprise-D Bridge, so we restored the main chairs and computers and took them on the road to over 22 conventions around the USA, where thousands of people sat in them and took photos for free.
Once we have the $82,300 secured to begin development for the museum, our next priority is to complete our Enterprise-D Bridge, rent a warehouse, move it and store it, which will take an additional $170,000. To restore our Star Trek: Original Series Bridge will cost roughly $150,000.
This will not only restore them "cosmetically" but make both sets better than they ever were using LED lights and original blueprints that will make them more accurate to the TV show.
Future museum plans include an exact replica of the Firefly/Serenity cockpit, Alien planet, the interior of the Star Wars Death Star, a full-sized X-Wing, the Millennium Falcon cockpit, an animatronic Cylon and much more!
NOTE: If you want more than one item, donate for an item then add the additional money to it (polo shirt $40 + $15 for a mug) then send us a note saying what the additional money is for.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have already taken many risks just to get this far, but our main challenges are obtaining the money to open our 2015 museum, and dealing with the studios and franchise owners to obtain the rights to create original interactive displays, instead of just static props sitting behind glass. We want to work closely with the studios, producers, actors, artists, writers, California Board of Education, NASA and JPL, the TV Academy, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, and the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce to make our exhibits entertaining as well as educational and inspirational.

Considering all the traction we have, plus our talented board of directors, fans from around the world who support us, and the powerful actors, producers and companies who want this to happen, it looks like our Hollywood Science Fiction Museum will be a tremendous success.

campaign.story:
I love movies. Especially low-budget sci-fi movies. I grew up watching old 1950s & 60s science fiction films with my dad, first on our own and then as part of the great "Mystery Science Theater 3000." Yet despite the inevitable mockery, I grew to love these movies and the strange aesthetics that they seemed bizarrely committed to. Put a man in a cardboard box and call him a "robot," and I'm in. The cheesier the better - I love it all.
In my business Alternate Histories, I take these b-grade monsters & aliens and add them to historic images to create visual art, greeting cards, and even a book! But I'm always looking for new projects. 
Recently I was browsing through books at East End Book Exchange, a great used bookstore near my house in Pittsburgh. I came across this 1892 annotated subscription copy of The Merchant of Venice.
The book that started it all!
Folios like this were produced as a way of sharing the great works of literature with a mass audience in a cheap & compact manner. I loved the look and feel of this book and thought to myself, "Why can't I do that with the movies that I love?"
With that, the Alternate Histories Classics of Filmdom series was born: we'll reproduce the look of these old folios but using the screenplays to low budget sci-fi movies as the text. The movies I picked are all cult classics, and they'll make great gifts, or fun little objects for you and your friends. Who wouldn't want to have a pocket-sized screenplay of "Plan 9 From Outer Space"?
The movies are:
-Plan 9 From Outer Space
-Manos the Hands of Fate
-Santa Claus Conquers the Martians
Here's a mock-up of the Plan 9 book.
I'll design all the books myself, but in order to get them printed responsibly and so they look great, they'll be printed by ScoutBooks, who use 100& recycled paper and print everything in the USA. Each book will be 3.5 x 5 inches and will fit perfectly in your pocket.
I need your help in funding this project, because it requires a big up-front investment. I feel like these books will sell really well, but in order to make them cost-effective, you have to print in really large quantities, which obviously costs a lot more. It's also more expensive to have them printed responsibly, but that's important to me, and I hope it's important to you too. 
It'll cost $3,000 to print the books, and the $2,000 left over will cover the shipping and fulfillment costs for the rewards.
I'll also design some limited-edition prints that you can only get through here - check out the levels to see what you can get if you contribute!
I love this idea and I think it's a fun way to share your love of bad sci-fi and good artwork. I hope you'll contribute!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Right now I'm in the middle of transcribing the films and designing the layout. You can see a sample of the Plan 9 test book in the video and above. It's a lot of work, but my goal is to have these books ready to print by the middle of July. Once they go to ScoutBooks, it takes 14 business days to print, and another 5-6 days for delivery to me in bulk. After that, I'll have to ship them out. I'm hoping to have books in hand to people by the middle to end of August at the latest.

Obviously this can be complicated if I run into problems with the layout, or my own business gets busy - but summer is normally a slower time, so I'm not anticipating any problems. All of the movies are in public domain, which means there aren't any problems with copyright infringement.

ScoutBooks is an established company with a great track-record. I'm confident that they'll do a great job printing these books.

The biggest problem will probably be shipping and fulfilling all of the orders as they come in, but this is already a big part of my business. I sell things online and ship them for a living, so I feel good about handling a mass mailing of books, even if it'll take a few days to complete.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Tickets are $5, and they all go to benefit the Greater Pittsburgh Community Food Bank. And hey, you can get a beer while you watch the show!

updates.update_content: Wow! With 10 days left we're 80% funded! Thank you so much to everyone who has contributed and shared - a lot of our contributions are coming from referrals on Facebook, so I really appreciate that help!

Wow! We've already hit $2,000 in just five days! Thanks so much to everyone who has backed this wacky project already! If you haven't shared this project, please feel free to do so! Word of mouth is the best way to get projects funded!
I'm hard at work transcribing Santa Claus Conquers the Martians (which is not quite as fun as it seems) and working on ideas for the limited-edition Plan 9 and Manos prints. I've included a few of the Plan 9 ones below so you can see what I'm working on - right now parodies of famous movie posters. I may or may not use one of these, but a lot of the time this kind of brainstorming leads to something else. And what the heck, they're a lot of fun.

campaign.story:
LIVV wireless headphones stay on your head, no matter how hard you play. They are lightweight, waterproof, and they sound amazing. 
#LIVVFREE
In 2008, Baltimore Ravens wide out Mark Clayton was running routine drills. An out route—he ran down the field and then cut a sharp 90 degree angle to the sideline, before he heard a SNAP! His headphones, which were home to the motivational soundtrack of his workout, had fallen off and been damaged by hard terrain. $300 headgear reduced to wires. 
That was easily the 10th pair of headphones used during training that Mark broke and he decided that would be the last one. Since then, Mark has spent six years developing his dream pair of Over-Ear Headphones. 

Introducing, LIVV.
The name LIVV was inspired by the ability to Live Free - free to move however you want, with no restrictions, no limitations. 

These are not athletic earbuds.  First of its kind, LIVV is a full-sized, over-ear headphone, designed never fall off your head, no matter how hard you play. #LIVVFREE

Wireless 
Lightweight
Water & sweat resistant
Amazing sounding
Features
On-board audio storage; capable of playing hours of clear, crisp beats.
Fully functional bluetooth headset, allowing you hands-free ability to make and receive calls.
How does it work?
Traditional headbands simply go over the crown of the head.  The more it needs to stay on your head, the greater the pressure it will have to exert on your ears... like an egg in a vise! 
The Contorsional headband on the LIVV Headphone is the 1st of its kind. Its unique, patent-pending design disperses the right amount of pressure across three key areas on the head.  This spreads across the total pressure effectively and evenly, ensuring a comfortably and extremely secure fit.  
We believe this will change how people want their headphones to fit from now on.  
Our goal is to build headphones that are light, comfortable, and very functional. LIVV will be your go-to earphone for doing anything from sitting and reading or studying to hanging upside down doing an intense set of abs or training full speed in any sport you can think of. This is true freedom and what it means to #LIVVFree
LIVV Technical specs 
Bluetooth 4.0 
AptX Codec
40mm titanium dynamic drivers
5.5oz
4-5 Hours of Continuous Playback or Talktime
5 Gb onboard memory
iPhone®, Android® and Windows® phones compatible 
Aurisonics, Inc. is a Nashville, TN (Music City) based professional audio product company. Aurisonics was founded in 2011 by veteran master audio engineer and audio products designer Dale Lott, with the goal of making products that truly allow customers to "hear it" and "live it."
When you pledge for a set of LIVV headphones, be rest assured that LIVV has been engineered not only to stay on your head comfortably, but to also sound insanely good.  
IntriCon Corporation is a listed company in the USA (NASDAQ: IIN) and they are a contract manufacturer for many of the world's leading audio companies.   
We have appointed them as our contract manufacturer for LIVV.   
With their expertise in manufacturing, you can be certain that the build quality of LIVV headphones will be incredible.  They have the expertise, know-how and capacity to ensure that there are no delays in fulfilment of pledges.
Rewards
We've been working on the LIVV Headset for over 3 years now. 
We have completed one real, working prototype. With your support, we can take the #LIVVFree lifestyle worldwide. 
Putting on the final touches
Your contribution will help fund
Finalized Software 
Production Tooling 
Large Component Order 
Global Bluetooth Certification 
Innovative Packaging Design 
Project timeline
Jun 2014: Set up tooling and production line 
Aug 2014: 1st run of Mechanical headphones 
Dec 2014: Complete programming of board for headphones 
Jan - Feb 2015: Finalise assembly line, run final build for testing
Mar 2015: Begin production of LIVV headphones 
Apr 2015: Start shipping out to backers! 
Thank you!
Meet the team
Mark Clayton / Dale Lott / Grayson Estes / Chern Wei / Kyle Lollis / Jason Thomas Lambrada / Drew Winter / Miller Creative / Stephen Gould Firm / Intricon Manufacturing / Marshall Manufacturing/ OMS Fulfillment Center / Music by Stephen Swartz
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
LIVV is engineered by audio engineer maestro, Dale Lott (Aurisonics Inc.) and is built by IntriCon Corporation (NASDAQ: IIN), with its production facilities in USA and Singapore. IntriCon is a contract manufacturer for many of the world's leading audio companies.

The LIVV and Aurisonics teams began collaborating almost two years ago. As the design progressed, we worked closely with Aurisonics to ensure the product was designed for high quality, high volume production.

We are just about to begin our tooling for first samples of the mechanical design, which will be used to build 50 units for testing, including wearing tests by top athletes, as well as listening tests by music artistes and audio experts. For these units we designed and built the circuit boards and did final assembly in Nashville TN.

Our next step is to setup the tooling and production line. We plan to build 50 units for more testing. Once we are fully satisfied with our mechanical design, we will proceed to complete the programming of the board for the headphones. 

We will then work with IntriCon to build out the final assembly line, install the test equipment, and do one more build before beginning production.

After several generations of prototypes and successive improvements, the latest generation has undergone extensive testing for over 12 months. We now need to complete the final iteration of the design, conduct extensive testing of the headphone, and move into production.

We plan to start production in March 2015 and begin delivering rewards to our supporters in April 2015. We will be keeping our backers updated on our progress through the various stages of our development and production process.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Mark, here is support from the other side of the globe. Go for it, this is great product. Cheers.
Hey Mark, I have a few questions, first how long does it take to fully charge the headphones and secondly can I take if for a swim? =)

I'm sure I will have more specific ideas and questions when I can examine the product better on my laptop instead of the KS iOS app. However, in the meantime, I did want to introduce myself and thank you for hooking up with Aurisonics! Several of us were quite vocal with ideas/feedback for Rockets -- and Dale was extremely receptive of hearing and integrating our ideas! The collaborative spirit among backers is what makes KS awesome (as opposed to other crowdfunding platforms that sadly lack this), and I look forward to the LIVV discussion that will soon ensue! :-D
Knowing you're working with Dale and Aurisonics in itself will give a lot of people confidence as they are excellent in their field!
Sorry for the long comment btw lol

Finally, I noticed that the girl that got out of the convertible in the video didn't have the headband touching the back of her head a couple of times. Are these adjustable or does it only adhere to a certain size/shape of head?

How has the comfort level been with workouts on those who have tested your prototype so far? I'm more specifically referring to the possible heat build up with an over the ear design while being used for intense activity and/or in hot environments. The last few days around here have been in the upper 90's which can cause some problems when you're trapping heat!
Wonderful. Thank you for the quick reply!
2) Can I double my pledge to get two at the supersteal price or how would that work for me to get a second pair?
Perfect, i can't wait untill april. I've never seen wireless headphones with a tolarable audio quality before, these could sound better then any wired headphones ever could!

campaign.story:
PROJECT UPDATE:
Thanks to one very generous backer, we have reached our initial goal of £2,000. However, this was the BARE MINIMUM amount needed and I still have a pile of handwritten letters to go out in the post and have 1000 leaflets coming to me in the post, so the campaign must go on! Our new goal is £3,000. With £3,000 we can rent better filming equipment, pay the actors properly, pay for a prop maker to make the Reed and Lucy dolls rather than relying on Ebay, pay for a storyboard artist, budget in another day of filming to ensure everything is the best it can be (I'm getting ahead of myself here, but the possibilities are limitless!). Please continue to help us make what will be not only a GORE-IOUS film, but also now a SPOOK-TACULAR film, a TERROR-IFIC FILM, a SCARE-TASTIC FILM!!! And a massive thank you again to our £1,500 hole in one pledger, Gordon Sutton, who I'm looking forward to meeting! 
STORY
Reed and Lucy are enjoying a day in an amusement arcade. After winning a small prize on a 2p machine, the young couple fail to notice the appearance of two dolls behind the glass that bear a haunting resemblance to them. Their game of Crazy Golf starts in good spirits, but as Reed begins to lose the game he begins to lose his mind, and as the two dolls veer toward the edge of the machine, Reed’s competitive nature veers towards homicidal. It’s going to be GORE-ious!
INSPIRATION
Whilst writing the script and envisioning the shoot I have been predominantly inspired by The Shining (1980), Braindead (1992), The Wicker Man (1973) and The Evil Dead (1981). Also, tv and films from my youth such as The Queen's Nose (1995-2003) and The Witches (1990).
Excessive gore & freaky voodoo magic.
MOOD
2p machine
Crazy Golf
Dolls Behind the Glass ©Tan Napat Kositpipat
Handing Over the Clubs ©Tan Napat Kositpipat
It's Just a Game © Tan Napat Kositpipat
MUSIC.
Music is what makes a horror movie and we have the very talented Patrick McManus on board who has already been preparing music for the film. We will be going for an electronic heavy, retro horror movie soundtrack. Inspired by the 'Tubular Bells' song from The Exorcist, we will be aiming for an iconic, memorable soundtrack which is present throughout the film. 
Here's a taster of the kind of sounds we'll be hearing.
WHY WE NEED MONEY.
- Costumes, Props & Make up effects. 
In order to emphasise their possession and the voodoo hold the machine has over Reed and Lucy I want to use black and red bloodshot Sclera contact lenses which cover the whole eye. These alone cost £63 a pair and we will need spares incase any break.
Sclera lenses
We also need small doll models of Reed and Lucy which will be inside the 2p machine. I originally thought of these being knitted characters, but have since decided that they wouldn't be menacing enough. FIMO (polymer clay) models are what we are going to be getting specially made for the film. Here is an example of what they will look like:
2p Machine Dolls
The film will also have two violent hallucination scenes. 
The first involves Reed putting his hand inside the golf hole to pick up the ball, and pulling his hand out to find his fingers have been severed off. For these shots we are using the special effects make up and skills of Maud Whatley:
© Maud Whatley
  © Maud Whatley
In the second hallucination scene Reed looks down in the golf hole and sees a closed eyeball inside before It opens and stares up at him. For this shot a model replica of a golf hole will have to be made so it will realistically look like something is under the ground looking up.
We will also need excessive amounts of fake blood and foam golf clubs, so no one gets hurt.
- Locations. 
We want to hire out a Crazy Golf Course for 2 days so we haven't got to worry about members of the public disturbing the shoot or a lack of variety when it comes to shots around the Crazy Golf course. 
We also want to hire out an Arcade for a day.
- Crew Equipment.
When filming in the Arcade for a day we will need lighting. We will also need to hire a professional sound mixer so we aren't relying on cameras to pick up the sound.
- Expenses.
For the cast and crew's train fares and petrol to and from the shooting locations. Also for food and drink, insurance and small things like sun tan lotion on set. The three days of shoot will be long ones so everyone on set will need to be adequately fed with at least a breakfast and lunch.
We also need to pay for our actors.
CAST
REED will be played by SHAUN CHAMBERS. Shaun trained at the Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts, graduating in 2012 with the GYEARBUOR Asante prize for acting. His credits include playing Eddie Carbone in A View from the Bridge at the Arcola Tent, Dillon in Equally at the Cockpit Theatre and has starred in short films Pandemonium and A Moments Matter. 
Shaun Chambers
 I am also thrilled to confirm that JENSON ZHU, this years Britains Got Talent semi-finalist comedy impersonator will be playing the role of the CRAZY GOLF COURSE ASSISTANT! He was hilarious on the show, terrible at impersonations and will be a wonderfully freaky little addition to the film.
We will be casting for the role of Lucy and other small roles this month. All pledgers will be kept updated on our progress!
CREW
Chloe Philippou: Writer/Director/Producer
Chloe Philippou graduated in 2013 with a degree in English and is a North London based filmmaker. Her first short film ITCH was selected and screened at Lindfield Arts Festival and her experience includes freelance script development work with Angeli Macfarlane and working alongside film director Gabriel Range.
Sapphire Sherbird: 1st Assistant Director/ Producer  
Sapphire is a London based 1st assistant director who has worked on 15 productions within the past 2 years. She is currently studying filmmaking at Kingston University and has recently had one of her short films selected to be screened at the Southbank BFI (British Film Institute).
Barnaby Walter: Executive Producer
Barnaby has worked as a writer, film critic, magazine editor and website advisor. He graduated from The University of Southampton last year with a BA in Film & English and his dissertation on the Hostel Series went on to be acclaimed by director Eli Roth. He is currently studying for a Masters degree in Film & Cultural Management and is Film Editor for The National Student.
Andrea Zabala Wynn: Director of Photography
Andrea graduated with a degree in English & Creative writing at Warwick University and went on to study music arranging & sound engineering for a year.
After that she moved across into the visual side of filmmaking by studying practical filmmaking at the MET. Since graduating she has been freelancing as a DoP / Camera Operator both in London and Barcelona.
Philip Reinking: Editor
Philip came to the UK from Germany 1 and a half years ago and has been editing and making films since he was 12. A film he made in 2010 was featured on the German release of Saw 7 on DVD and BluRay. He is currently studying filmmaking at Kingston University and also has a film selected to be screened at the Southbank BFI (British Film Institute). 
Maud Whatley: Costume & SFX Makeup
For two summer seasons from 2007 to 2008 Maud represented the wardrobe and costume department with The National Youth Theatre, including the run of 20 Cigarettes at the Soho Theatre. She was a production assistant for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival show A Little Bit of Dickens in 2013, frequently illustrates websites and is self trained at Special Effects makeup.
Jack O'Halloran: Locations Manager
Jack is a freelance film production researcher/co-ordinator who works predominantly on art history documentaries. Most recently he worked on the live cinema broadcast 'Matisse Live from Tate Modern'.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Risks and challenges are what making a film is all about. From weather problems on the shoot days to people dropping out. Luckily a few members of our team are affiliated with filmmaking Universities, so their facilities and students are things we can fall back on if plans go wrong. We are also arranging back up filming locations. Ultimately, all the crew are experienced in making films and are dedicated to seeing this through to the end.

Thank you for reading, and THANK YOU SO MUCH if you decide to help us out.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
When the human race turns to dust, the few survivors must find each other before they are found. Their journey begins...at the end.
"Just when you think that 21st-century authors have come up with every possible way of destroying the world, along comes Jeremy Robinson." —New Hampshire Magazine
In addition to creating a vivid and powerful short film with the hope of entertaining our audience, DUST will be used as a “proof of concept” film, allowing us to generate interest in creating a feature-length film, based on the novel, The Distance. The ultimate career goals for both Ken Dodge and Jeremy Robinson have always been to make feature films. A high-quality short puts that goal in reach and puts this moving science-fiction story one big step closer to the silver screen.
Peter, a young man and blogger, is spending the evening with his parents. It’s a typical evening filled with frustrating parental conversation, dinner and television. But when a strange grinding noise fills the air, frantic news reports come from the TV, and then the power goes out, their night is cut short. What happens next changes the lives of every person living on planet Earth—Peter’s more than most—because unlike untold billions, he is one of few who survives the event...and encounters those responsible for it.
DUST follows a single character witnessing the end of humanity. It is a standalone story that parallels the events in the upcoming post-apocalyptic sci-fi thriller novel, The Distance, by bestselling author, Jeremy Robinson, and his wife, Hilaree Robinson.
THEIR JOURNEY BEGINS...
On the night Poe McDowell visits her parents, the topic of discussion ranges from art and poetry to the small baby growing in her belly. The comforts of home and family help to ease her concerns over raising a child alone. But when a grinding noise fills the air, the night’s peace is shattered. Her parents, in a panic, drag her to the basement, shove her inside a strange, coffin-like device and before the door is closed, turn to dust.
Twenty seven hundred miles away, and two miles deep, at Arizona’s Dark Matter Research Center, August Morrison is oblivious to the strange phenomenon sweeping across the planet. When he rises from the depths, he finds his co-workers reduced to a fine white powder that fills the air, his mouth and his lungs. The human race has been reduced to dust—overnight.
Alone on opposite ends of the country, Poe and August discover each other through the HAM radio network, beginning a cross-country trek as August heads from Arizona to New Hampshire. But they soon discover that they’re not alone. The human race’s demise was not natural, and the architects are searching for survivors.
...AT THE END
Kenneth Dodge is the Telley award-winning director and editor behind scores of commercials and online promotional videos for clients such as: DTS, Sony, Carl's Jr., Mazda, Konami, The U.S. Army, ZICO and NBC/Universal. His sixteen years of professional experience, working with a range of budgets, has given him exceptional skill behind the camera as well as in the editor's chair, enabling him to fully execute his vision.
Dodge began his film career at the age of 16, using his sister's VHS camera, filming dance recitals, hundreds of "film-school" shorts (that no one will ever see) and finally receiving a BA in film from Emerson College. 
For more about Ken, visit: www.kennethdodge.com.
Samples of Ken's work:
Jeremy Robinson is the bestselling author of more than forty novels and novellas, including Xom-B, Island 731, SecondWorld, the Jack Sigler thriller series and Project Nemesis, the highest selling original (non-licensed) kaiju novel of all time. He's known for mixing elements of science, history and mythology, which has earned him the #1 spot in Science Fiction and Action-Adventure, and secured him as the top creature feature author.
Robinson began his creative career as a comic book illustrator and writer before turning to screenwriting and selling The Screenplay Workbook (Random House), and shifting his focus to novels. Robinson is also known as the #1 Amazon.com horror writer, Jeremy Bishop, author of The Sentinel and the controversial novel, Torment. His novels have been translated into eleven languages. He lives in New Hampshire with his wife and three children. 
For more about Robinson, visit: www.jeremyrobinsononline.com.
"Robinson puts his distinctive mark on Michael Crichton territory with this terrifying present-day riff on The Island of Dr. Moreau. Action and scientific explanation are appropriately proportioned, making this one of the best Jurassic Park successors." —Publisher's Weekly - Starred Review for Island 731
Jeremy's most recent hardcover trailer:

Samples of projects Ken and Jeremy have worked on together:
Hilaree Robinson is a long time writer, influenced by greats such as Margaret Atwood and Madeline L’Engle. The Distance is her debut novel. When not writing, she can be found in her art studio, creating works for display in local galleries, hiking the woods of New Hampshire or homeschooling her three children.
Originally hailing from New England, Matt moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in Special Effects. Matt has worked on films like I AM LEGEND, Martin Scorsese’s SHUTTER ISLAND, and Frank Miller’s 300 during his twelve years in the world of Special Effects and Makeup, as well as on TV shows such as CRIMINAL MINDS, WIZARDS OF WAVERLY PLACE, and NBC’s GRIMM. He also created alien prosthetics for STAR TREK - INTO DARKNESS.
 Chris Munton has always had a love for unsettling cinema. Inspired by horror flicks of the ‘70s and ‘80s, he seeks to push the envelope in psychologically disturbing soundscapes. Having collaborated with Ken Dodge on film projects since their college years, they share a common vision of paranoia. Major influences include Stephen King and Stanley Kubrick.
All funds raised will go directly into the production and release of DUST. We will be using professionals every step of the way, working with casting companies, actors, sound designers, composers, make-up artists, practical and digital effects companies and various other creative and technical contributors. Our goal is to film the entire 10–12 minute short in two, tightly scheduled days (which is how we’ve kept the budget as low as it is). While those of us directly involved in the film’s creation (Ken and Jeremy) will not be paid for our efforts, almost everyone else will be paid. A good portion of the non-stretch goal funding will go directly to our practical effects, which are going to be unique and potentially ground breaking.
Stretch Goal #1: If we reach $30,000, the film will include a bonus scene featuring August, leading directly into the novel. This will also allow us to use the short film as a long-form book trailer.
Stretch Goal #2: If we reach $40,000, the film will include the above mentioned scene with August, AND we'll be taking the film to major film festivals. While we’re already planning to attend a few on our own dime, hitting this goal will allow us to visit all the big festivals for maximum exposure. Money will cover festival fees and travel. Festivals we intend to show the film at include: SXSW, Cannes, Sundance, Toronto, Telluride, New York Film Fest and New Hampshire Film Expo.
Stretch Goal #3: If we reach $60,000, we will be endeavoring to include a well-recognized actor in the production, most likely in the leading role. We have a short list of actors we would like to play the role of Peter, but can’t make them a reasonable offer to star in the film unless we hit this number.
Stretch Goal #4: If we reach $1,000,000, we will make the short into a feature-length film, no production company or movie studio required. Let’s face it, if Kung Fury didn’t reach this stretch goal, we probably won’t either. BUT, if we do, we will film a complete adaptation of The Distance for theatrical release.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
With our team assembled and all equipment already in hand, there is very little risk involved with this project. All we really need is funding support! And that's where our small amount of risk comes from. There is a small chance that our practical effects, which are going to be unique, might run over budget. If that happens, the film's "producer", Jeremy Robinson, who will be partially funding the project even with your help, will cover the difference.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Good News - We're making a movie!
updates.update_content: CASTING CALL! Director, Kenneth Dodge and I are making a horror short film, THE OWL, and if you're an actor (and match a role) we want to hear from you! We will be filming, in New Hampshire, October 17 - 19. Virtual auditions start now. In person casting (in Portsmouth, NH) is on Sept 6, with callbacks on the 13th. Follow the link for full casting call details:

It's probably clear to you (as it is to us) that short of a last minute wealthy benefactor, the DUST Kickstarter is going to fall short of its ambitious goal. While this is disappointing, it's not the end! Not by a long shot. 
Ken and I are already working on a replacement short film that doesn't require the insane special effects that DUST would. Thus, I can fund the filming and editing my own bad self. We might return to Kickstarter to fund the short's release to fans, and to festivals, but this one is getting made, no matter what. The script is already done, and we're planning to cast it soon, and probably film in the next two months.

campaign.story:
Do you often reminisce about what it was like "back in the day"? Have you ever thought to yourself... 

"Wow, I sure do love this old school slow jam, but it would be nice to get a fresh new spin on it -- really flip the script and hear what it could sound like with vocals and guitar... maybe a few tasteful harmonies."?

ME TOO.
I present to you Acoustic Throwback. Naked arrangements of your favorite 90s R&B jams. Let's take a ride on a six-string time machine back to when MTV still had videos, and you still had a landline phone (and an answering machine).
As much as I love to cover songs, I'm not a fan of most cover songs, because the majority just copy the original without adding anything new, and that's not what I'm after. Take this Mariah tune for example.
Honestly, I wasn't planning to Kickstart this project since I didn't want to overwhelm you, my biggest supporters, or make you feel like my hand was always out. But strangely, a lot of you asked me to launch on Kickstarter and I realized something. Crowdfunding isn't just about raising money, it's about the community and being invested in something WITH the artist. It's about being a part of the whole. 
Also, let me add how grateful I am to have a job I love, where I get to dream up ridiculous stuff like this and have you along for the ride. It means more to me than you probably will ever know. 

I have you to keep me grounded -- to remind me not to go chasing waterfalls.
Trying to narrow down my favorite 90s R&B songs is no easy task. I'm aiming for tracks that are recognizable with the occasional "deep cut", but would also translate well to a new acoustic arrangement. So, here's what I'm thinking. If the project is successfully funded, I will pick 6-7 songs, with 3 more songs being chosen by popular vote, and up to 3 additional songs chosen from the "Custom Song Request" backers for a total of at least 10-12 tracks. Here's a HUGE list of songs with YouTube links to get some ideas from. 
I plan to have a LOT of cameos and have already started lining them up. As tempting as it is to tell you who all has agreed to do this, it's way more fun to leave you guessing  : ]. Stay tuned throughout the funding period as I'll be announcing new guest artists every few days. 
FIRST HINTS:
Melissa Polinar
M____ B______
M____ B________
J_____ C_____
E___ H_________
M____ G_____
J____ H____
T___ L____
C_____ P______
J______ P______
N______ A______
D____ C_______
D_____ R____ H______
A_____ P____
E______ Y____

See if you can guess. These are just some of the people that *could* do it and have expressed interest. There's no guarantee all of these will work out due to scheduling and logistics, but I'm gonna try!
Stretch goals are rewards that everyone gets when the project funding reaches certain levels. So, if the project reaches...

$1,990 (REACHED) CARLTON DANCE - I'll post a video of me doing The Carlton Dance! (Couldn't fit it all on Instagram so decided to make it an official backer update).

$10,000 (REACHED) - EXTRA BONUS SONG not available anywhere else. Just for you lovely people!

$20,000 - NASHVILLE CD RELEASE SHOW. If we cross the $20k mark I'll throw a Nashville Release show. Backers at the $20 level and higher will get an invite and a plus one. 
Here's a photo of me, from 1993, at my senior prom. My friend Samantha thought it would be fun to "do my hair", so I let her. Not sure what the bolo tie is all about. 
Anyways, just wanted y'all to know you're in good hands.
UPDATES
Update #3 [6/24/14] - Passed the $16,000 mark, WOW! Revealed 2 of the special guests (Melissa Polinar, and Tony Lucca). Released a video update for backers only. Also, I started officially recording. Why wait until the funding deadline? I'm ready to do this!
Update #2 [6/11/14] - Added some hints to the special guest section below. See if you can figure out some of the cameos. Also, not even 24 hours yet and we just might pass the $10,000 mark! Unreal!
Update #1 [6/10/14] - Holy crap! Initial funding goal is history! We're at the 300% mark and it's still the first night! This project has got some legs. THANK YOU for getting involved and spreading the word! As promised I did The Carlton Dance as the first stretch goal reward. Check the UPDATES section for the video. Also, be sure to check the STRETCH GOALS section below as I'll be adding more of them as we reach them TOGETHER. Ok, now group hug. Bring it in....
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
An endeavor such as this won't be without certain challenges. Since I am not the copyright owner of these songs, proper steps must be taken to license the works so that the original authors get paid. (The statutory mechanical rate is currently 9.1 cents per song per unit sold). Fortunately, I'm familiar with the process by now. 

I am REALLY excited and passionate about this project, for real. 

LET'S DO THIS!

-E$

PS.
Big thank you to my friend Stephanie Orefice (@stephanieamber) who helped me shoot this Kickstarter video, and to many of you who've offered great feedback and suggestions along the way, you know who you are.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hey everyone!

Just to keep you updated, I'll be organizing all the packages and printing labels this week and next. Had ordered a BUNCH of stuff and it took time to design, custom print and receive it all. The last thing I was waiting for were the cassette tapes and they look awesome, as do the slap bracelets, the neon green fanny packs, the color changing touch-me t-shirts. e$

Playas & Playettes

campaign.story:
"The Holoscenes project is a bold and outrageous response to an anxiety that most thinking persons around the planet have in the face of impending disaster. It is so outlandish and unlikely in its conception that, should it succeed, it will truly define this moment we are living through and promises to be a thoughtful and provocative take on the artist's ability to "be out in front" shaping a discourse as well as touching our hearts.”       — Bill T. Jones
HOLOSCENES is an epic public art and performance installation that is a visual, visceral response to climate change.  Help us raise funds to complete the centerpiece of HOLOSCENES:  a massive, hydraulically-animated aquarium that creates floods around performers.
WHY WE'RE MAKING HOLOSCENES
My name is Lars and I direct a collaborative performance + art lab called Early Morning Opera. We're making HOLOSCENES because we're concerned that our relationship to water will become the central issue of the 21st century, and we believe that art can be a powerful vehicle for communicating the complex phenomenon of climate change to a broad audience. 
Presented in public space, the centerpiece of HOLOSCENES is a large aquarium that floods, drains, and floods again by way of a hydraulic system that moves 12 tons of water in a minute. The aquarium is inhabited by a performer conducting one of many everyday behaviors sourced from collaborators across the planet.
YES, AS BILL T. JONES SAYS, IT'S AN "OUTRAGEOUS" PROJECT... BUT SEVERAL PRESENTATIONS ARE ALREADY CONFIRMED
We will premier HOLOSCENES at the Toronto Nuit Blanche Festival (October 4, 2014)— an all-night festival that is one of the largest art events in North America.  And then we are going to present at the John & Mable Ringling Museum of Art (March 2015) in Sarasota, FL — positioned right on the Gulf of Mexico, on a spot that is predicted to be underwater in 20 years.  And then, at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts (October 2015) in downtown San Francisco.  And we're in advanced conversations with institutions in several other cities.  
WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT 
But, the most important part of the project — the first aquarium — hasn't been built yet. We've raised enough money to get to this point, and we have half the money we need to build the aquarium.  Now we need to raise another $41,000 to complete the fabrication... or we don't premier this fall.
If you can help us by donating, thank you thank you thank you. Whether you can give or not, please follow us on Facebook or Twitter, and share the project with anyone you think might be interested. SPREADING THE WORD IS HUGELY HELPFUL.  
HOW WE GOT HERE
An incredibly diverse team of art, engineering, and science collaborators has spent three years developing HOLOSCENES, including Pablo N. Molina, Geoff Sobelle, Annie Saunders, Irina Kruzhilina, Nathan Ruyle, Chris Kuhl, Eric Lin, Peter Zuspan, and Blaine O'Neill, with major contributions from many others, including several science advisors and the arts/science consortium PositiveFeedback USA, based at Columbia University's Earth Institute. Working alongside us all along have been the incredible non-profit producers, MAPP International Productions. During that time, we've: 
CONDUCTED EARLY DESIGN WORKSHOPS:
Holoscenes 3 Aquarium concept rendering (by Peter Zuspan / Bureau V)
REHEARSED IN COMMUNITY POOLS BETWEEN SWIM LESSONS:
Sophie Bortolussi cutting fabric / Oct 2012 (photo by Lars Jan)
TESTED OUR IDEAS ON DRY LAND:
Aquarium scale experiments @ Center for the Art of Performance @ UCLA (CAP UCLA) / Feb 2013 (featuring Annie Saunders and photoshop)
AND PROTOTYPED OUR HYDRAULIC SYSTEM, WHILE DEVELOPING CHOREOGRAPHY, SAFETY, SOUND, COSTUME, VIDEO AND PHOTOGRAPHIC ELEMENTS:
Prototype Workshop @ the Experimental Media and Performing Arts Center (EMPAC) / July 2013 (photo by Kris Qua)
Video captured during Prototype workshop @ EMPAC / featuring choreographer & performer Geoff Sobelle
These initial phases of the project have been supported by two grants from the National Endowment of the Arts; awards from the Rockefeller MAP Fund, New York State Council on the Arts, Panta Rhea Foundation, Awesome Without Borders, and many individual donors; commissions from the John & Mable Ringling Museum of Art and Yerba Buena Center for the Arts; as well as critical residencies from CAP UCLA and long-time Early Morning Opera supporter EMPAC.  
Also, we've received submissions from people around the world, whose videos of their own lives we use to create the everyday behaviors choreographed within the aquarium.  
THE PROJECT CAN BE EXPERIENCED IN MANY WAYS
In addition to the flagship performance installation in public space, HOLOSCENES includes videos and photographs — which will be shown in my first solo show, at the Pasadena Museum of California Art (PMCA) from January to May 2015. The five photographs below, captured during our prototype workshop, will be included in the show at PMCA, and can be received by our Kickstarter backers — maybe you?  
Abaya / 2013 / photograph by Lars Jan
Hunter / 2013 / photograph by Lars Jan
Charleston / 2013 / photograph by Lars Jan
Untitled / 2013 / photograph by Lars Jan
Phone Sextet / 2013 / photograph by Lars Jan
AND HOLOSCENES IS AN EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY
During the performances, freely distributed printed materials created with our team of science advisors and writers add context to the project and access to our various streams of research.  These materials will help supplement related events, conversations, and study-groups organized by our host institutions, and will eventually find its way online to serve as both a free educational resource and window into the making of HOLOSCENES.
These materials, as well as some of our rewards (such as the poster below), are created in collaboration with Cooper-Hewitt award-winner Rick Valicenti and Bud Rodecker at Thirst.  
HOLOSCENES poster / edition of 250 / designed by Thirst
THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU
FOR READING THIS FAR  
FOR GIVING IF YOU CAN
FOR SPREADING THE WORD
AND FOR PARTICIPATING IN OUR VISION.
FULL-HEARTED GRATEFULLY,
LARS & the HOLOSCENES team
+++++++++++++++++++++++
MORE REWARD INFO
+ Here's an example of our previous originally composed Chant for Gratitude — a backer favorite — from when our show ABACUS raised funds to go to the Sundance Film Festival.  We'll make a brand new one...maybe underwater...for you :)
+ Women's & Men's high-quality cotton T-shirts (any size), designed by Thirst.
 + Hand screen-printed Golden Ticket, good for admittance to any Early Morning  Opera event beginning October 2014. Designed by Wilson Kello.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Our biggest challenge with HOLOSCENES has always been its scale, both in terms of the resources required to complete it and the complexity of the various systems involved. We have overcome many major design, logistic and financial hurdles over the past three years and have built a huge network of support along the way. The project deals with huge quantities of water and power, and so we won't be able to fully test the aquarium, and know the full breadth of requirements to operate it efficiently and safely, until it is built. 

Because the design for aquarium is a new one, we are taking the implementation of redundant safety systems and protocol very seriously, but I'm sure we'll need to develop our safety procedures even further once we can use the real, functional aquarium.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: THE WHITE ALBUM by JOAN DIDION / a new performance
updates.update_content:
Thank you for supporting HOLOSCENES four years ago! It's gone on to tour around the US and the world, and is still going! 
I'm working on another ambitious performance — this one constructed around Joan Didion’s seminal essay, THE WHITE ALBUM, and could use your help again to make another challenging, unique live performance happen. 
Please take a look at the project's Kickstarter page to learn more: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/larsjan/joan-didions-the-white-album
Anything you can do to support or spread the word helps!

Learn more about our performances of HOLOSCENES in Miami last week from this great story in the New York Times that landed on the cover of the National section.  We reached thousands of viewers with 24 hours of performance over 4 days, and now we're working to lock in a world tour that may include Athens, London, and Abu Dhabi in 2016.
Please consider supporting our newest work, The Institute of Memory (TIMe) — a personal piece about the evolution of both remembering and privacy in the digital age — as we prepare for the globally-influential Under the Radar Festival at the Public Theatre this January.

HOLOSCENES will have a rare series of outdoor public performances — 6 hours daily — hosted by MDC Live Arts during Art Basel Miami from December 2nd to 5th.   
Details here. 
Join us and / or tell your friends for this final US presentation before HOLOSCENES heads abroad!

FRIENDS,
We premiered HOLOSCENES in Toronto to phenomenal audience reaction during the all-night Nuit Blanche Festival on Oct 4/5th. Around 20,000 people saw the piece during the 12 hours of performance.

updates.update_userinfo: Aquarium Under Construction / International Call for Collaborators
updates.update_content:
Holoscenesters,
1) We're collecting short videos of everyday behaviors from people around the world to help us create HOLOSCENES — collaborate with us yourself, or share this link with anyone outside the US who might want to participate in our art & climate activism project:
http://www.holoscen.es/collaborate/ — DEADLINE IS JULY 31st.

We've down to the last hours of the campaign to fund HOLOSCENES. THANK YOU for your support along the way. 
Here's performer and free-diver Annie Saunders reading a a paper in our aquarium mockup, trying to imagine water rising and falling...via a projected simulation that's driven by the stock price of BP in 2012.  This is the scale of the aquarium we're so close to raising the funds to complete!

updates.update_userinfo: How we simulated an aquarium till now / 1 day, $8K / ALL OR NOTHING
updates.update_content:
"A person sits inside an aquarium. Suddenly, the tank floods with 12 tons of water, then drains, then floods again. The lesson? It'll be pretty hard to ignore global warming one day." - FastCompany on HOLOSCENES
Backers, Friends, Strangers!
Thanks for keeping up with the campaign down the home stretch.  WE'VE ONLY GOT 8 DAYS LEFT, and have raised over $14K from 166 AMAZING BACKERS.  If you've given, THANK YOU. If you're on the verge, please donate NOW, as your support will help bring others on board.

campaign.story:
Miss the kickstarter? Beta Access and Pre-Orders at TogetherTheGame.com will count towards stretch goals!
Stretch Goals
$15k Linux Support: Together: Amna & Saif will be released on Linux
$17k Mac Support: Together: Amna & Saif will be released on Mac
$20k New Game Plus: Replay the game, but the puzzles will be harder! That's almost double the puzzles!
$23k Pet Turtle: Hidden within the forest is a cute turtle, find him and he will follow you through the rest of the game.
The core of Together is interdependence. Everything requires two players, working together.  Designing co-op from the ground up we are able to explore and do things that would otherwise be impossible.
Every aspect of the game is designed for player interaction. To progress you have to think about what is best for each other, not just yourself. Together highlights the benefits that gaming can have on a relationship. It goes beyond having a conversation or doing something together. Interdependence is a key quality in a rewarding and successful relationship and Together allows you to experience and practice it in a tangible way. 
Together will release initially on PC. Additional platforms may become available as stretch goals. You will both be able to play using the same keyboard. Controllers and mouse will be supported as well.
Vote for us on steam greenlight
Some mechanics require you be together, other times apart. Some levels will require timing and coordination. Some levels seem simple at first, but playing them and only thinking about what you need instead of what you both need will result in failure.
Approachable
We believe that games are an art form and wish to bring the experience to new audiences. We have kept the controls simple and the core game friendly. This makes Together a great way to introduce the ones you love to gaming.
Challenge
In making the game approachable we didn't want to sacrifice depth either. There are optional objectives interwoven throughout the main campaign that even the most avid gamers find challenging.
Accessibility
Colors used in game mechanics were planned with the color blind in mind. Controls are kept simple to be accessible to as many people as possible. The game can be played with one hand. During the beta phase we will do everything we can to make the game playable for those with specific needs.
Strengthening Relationships
Together highlights the benefits that gaming can have on a relationship. It goes beyond having a conversation or doing something together. Interdependence is a key quality in a rewarding and successful relationship and Together allows you to experience and practice it in a tangible way.

You play as Amna and Saif, a mother and son. Your loved one has fallen deathly ill and the only chance of a cure lies deep within a mysterious forest. Only together can you overcome the trials of the landscape and the great beasts of the forest to find the cure in time.
Amna and Saif
We are happy to announce that Filippo Beck Peccoz will be doing the music and sound design for Together. Filippo has worked on a number of games. Most recently he finished the fantastic music and sound for The Last Tinker : City of Colors. Here is some music he created for Together. 
Posters:
Backers at the "physical rewards" tier will receive their choice of one of these beautiful prints created for Together
Pin and T-Shirt:
Designs for the Pin and T-Shirt have not been decided yet, we will open up voting for physical reward backers to decide designs.
Design a Level
If you can draw stick figures you can have a level in Together. It will have your name on it, if you want it too.  We will take your outline of a level and implement it in game for you.  You will then have the chance to get it play tested and talk to beta backers in the forums.  You will have the opportunity to make several rounds of changes before the game is released.
 Lyle Cox : Programming, Game Design - @LyleCox
I grew up making games and acting as a jungle gym for my younger siblings and cousins. I later learned to code and am now combining those skills into the creation of video games. Always striving to improve as a designer I will make Together the best game I can. I want people to have a bonding experience by playing Together with each other.
 Evan Munro : Art Director - @evanmunro1
While finishing my BA in painting and drawing from the University of Utah I took a quick detour into game design which completely took over my life. I love imagining distant landscapes and with games they can be explored . This is my third game project and second acting as art director. 
 Filippo Beck Peccoz : Audio Designer - fbpsound.com
A graduate of Berklee college of Music in Boston, I now make sounds and music exclusively for games from my hometown, Munich. I began recording myself singing along to Megaman tunes at the age of 6. I have a fascination for found sounds from household objects. My biggest inspirations are the work of Yuzo Koshiro and Thomas Newman!
 Becky Pennock : Animation - jeanox.tumblr.com
I'm a self taught digital painter and video game artist with a passion for collaborative work. I've participated in many projects that have been published (in web design, video game development, animation, and illustration). I've also been published in ImagineFX. I enjoy doing technical work that is also artistic. Balancing the necessary elements to make it all come together is very satisfying for me.
Why Kickstarter?
Reaching our goal will allow us to make Together the game it's meant to be. With extra character and environment animations and more time to add additional polish, Kickstarter will help make Together really stand out. Lyle has self funded the development of Together and will continue to do so, but backing Together will give us the boost to make the game even better. $10,000 is less than it will take to finish the game, but we are not asking kickstarter to burden all the risk. All the money raised will go towards paying Becky, Evan, and Filippo.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
During over a year of development on Together the vision for the project became clear. That was the most important part. We will now make the game the best that we can within that vision with the resources we have.

If the project is funded, the biggest risk is that we take longer than is estimated. The first line of defense against this is managing scope, which we will continue to do so that we don't run into this problem. We will do everything we can to meet our deadlines, but our first priority will be creating the best game possible. We thank you for backing the project and giving us the opportunity to make Together the best it can be.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Lot's has happened in my personal life that has halted development on Together: Amna & Saif for a time. Some of which I have talked about briefly in past updates. Things are getting back on track, and starting today I am able to put 3-4 hours in every Saturday to wrap up development. The game isn't too far away from being completed, so hopefully I will have more encouraging and concrete goals and timeline the next update I give you.
As for progress, at the beginning of the year I received the story from Saladin, which with the exception of some possible minor edits, will be the final version. I have already integrated it into the game. Next up in priority is the art for the ending and more iteration and refining levels in the latter half of the game.

updates.update_userinfo: Looking for testers to record their gameplay
updates.update_content:
Recovery
I am still recovering health wise from February. I was unable to work for 5 months and am now up to working 20-25 hours a week most of the time. Unfortunately a lot of that time has been doing contract work in order to keep food on the table. I am making slow but steady progress on Together and as I wrap up my current contract I will focus all my working time on Together. 
Sorry it is taking so long to finish the game.

updates.update_userinfo: Seriously sick, sorry for silence, steady steps
updates.update_content:
Hello, sorry it has been so long since the last update. In early February I got very sick, after a while I ended up in the hospital. Fortunately it wont cause any permanent harm. Months later, I am steadily recovering but i'm still not sure when I will be back to 100%. During that time I haven not made a lot of progress on Together. It also messed with my financial runway and my projected road-map for getting Together out to you.
I am excited that I have started easing back into working on Together. Unfortunately I still can't put an accurate estimate on the projected road-map because of my health. And the longer it takes to finish the game the more pressure it puts on finances which increases the likely hood I will need to get work somewhere so I can put food on the table and keep the lights on. That in turn would push the timeline for Together out further. In that scenario I would still try my best to work on Together during weekends wherever possible.

Events & Press
Together: Amna & Saif won runner up at Utah Game Wars which came with a small cash prize and a booth at Salt Lake City Comic Con. Over the last couple months I have showed the game at Salt Lake Gaming Con and PAX with the Indie Megabooth.
Pax and Gaming Con went well. At every show many people stick around to 100% clear the build being shown. At Salt Lake Gaming Con that took some people two to three hours. So that speaks well to how engaging the game can be.

Whats up?
The game as shown well at Pax East and several smaller local events. By adding some animations, tweaking some things, adding some levels and reordering others we have eliminated the hangups some players were running into trying to understand mechanics. At the most recent event in 7 hours on 2 stations 6 pairs of people played the 1 - 2 hour build to completion which is very encouraging.

A new build has been released. The game now saves your progress! For the full change log and updates you can check it out here. http://blog.mountolymp.us/?p=191
We now have players reaching out to each other when they get close. Aren't they cute!?

We have been hard at work on the game trying to be ready for our spring target date.
Beta keys should all be out. If you didn't get yours let me know and I will re-send it.
I just posted a progress update on the blog here. We are going to start trying to push out builds every 2 weeks.  There is a delay between me sending the build to humblebundle and them making it available so sadly I can't give a specific day of the week it should be expected.

campaign.story:
Feminist Science Fiction...
...are three words you don't normally hear together. If you Google them, you'll find some Margaret Atwood and Ursula K. LeGuin novels, but very few films. 
Why?
If you're like me, then you desperately want movies to be more universal, more accessible and more relevant to modern audiences. While it's always fun to watch 3D superheroes incur billions of dollars in damage to iconic cities, it's easy to forget that film has the potential to be smart, culturally relevant and down to Earth without sacrificing entertainment value. That's why We Can Speak to the Dead is very close to my heart. 
Built upon foundations set by feminist film critique, gender studies, sociology, and many other aspects of feminism, We Can Speak to the Dead will ask tough questions about society, cinema and our perceptions of gender while still being a frightening and excitingly good time.
A Story About Art and Technology
We Can Speak to the Dead follows Joyce, a subversive artist in Portland who stumbles onto a technological conspiracy that threatens her life and conscious autonomy. Imagine if Stepford Wives had a child with Invasion of the Body Snatchers and then raised it on a steady diet of Total Recall. 
Tiny Budget, Big Ideas
You might think that $5,000 is a lot of money, but in terms of film, it's actually not very much. Not even for a short. Since I already have a camera and field recorder, the entire budget is going where it should: towards hiring a great lead actor and cinematographer, acquiring a lens kit, commissioning some fantastic music and renting a steady-cam once or twice for smooth motion shots. The money earned here will be to acquire some equipment and pay those generous enough to be on my team. 
We Can Speak to the Dead is going to be shot on a bare-bones budget, but that's actually great because having fewer resources means needing bigger and more innovative ideas. We'll focus on natural lighting, in-lens effects and building suspense by mood and subtext, not a bunch of expensive crane shots. Since I am an experienced writer, director and editor, I can consolidate a substantial part of the budget by taking on many roles.  
Strong Female Characters
It seems like forever since Ripley first battled the Alien, subverting horror standards that still stand today. Even in the 21st century, it's hard to find sci-fi or horror films with female protagonists who don't play Lead Victim. Too often they spend the bulk of 90 minutes running away from something and shrieking, 
Wouldn't it be awesome for a dark science-fiction film, a la early Cronenberg, to have a lead female character as complex and interesting as those in a Kelly Reichart movie? Or as independent as Ripley in Alien? 
My main character, Joyce, doesn't comfortably fit into the mold traditionally set by Hollywood for female leads or gender stereotypes. Neither does she exist to be victimized or objectified. She's her own person with her own agenda, and while she faces some extremely onerous hurdles, she never resigns to be somebody's victim, and that's what makes We Can Speak to the Dead such a deep, personal project for me. 
A Short Film to Pave the Way
While We Can Speak to the Dead is only a small short film, it could be a big step for me as a filmmaker, and for showing that socially conscious sci-fi can still be challenging, intense and entertaining without a huge effects budget. 
We Can Speak to the Dead won't be an easy short film to forget. It's going to stick with you and linger. And while I've gone to great lengths to highlight the political subtext of the film, there's going to be plenty for newcomers and sci-fi/horror connoisseurs alike to enjoy. You won't have to be a sociology grad to appreciate its message or groove to its rhythm. 
The Team
Sara Copeland -- Lead Actor
Sara will play the main character in We Can Speak to the Dead
Sara is an actor living in Portland, Oregon. She has a passion for all theatre arts including acting, playwriting, directing, performance art, improv, and dramaturgy. She received her B.A. in Theatre & Performance Studies from Kennesaw State University in Kennesaw, GA in 2012 and has performed in a variety of venues from Atlanta, New York City, Portland, and Shanghai. She loves creating new works with other theatre artists and looks forward to any opportunity to work with the arts in her community. You can find out more about Sara at saraecopeland.weebly.com.
Richard Herbert -- Writer/Director/Editor
Richard will direct, edit and write We Can Speak to the Dead
 Richard Herbert is a writer, director, editor and photographer living in Portland, Oregon. He's an alumni of Spy Hop Productions and directed the winning short of Salt Lake City's 2012 48 Hour Film Festival, Tic. His films have been shown at international film festivals, including the Tribeca Youth Film Festival, and he has worked as a videographer for the past seven years. In college, he was one of 12 young filmmakers chosen nationwide to participate in Adobe's Youth Voices program at the Sundance Film Festival. 
As a writer, he's a recurring contributor to OverThinkingIt.com, using continental and feminist philosophy to analyze pop culture, and runs his own art and technology blog.
Josh Miller -- Composer
Josh will compose the music for We Can Speak to the Dead
Josh Miller is a composer and computer science wiz living in San Antonio, Texas. His work focuses on setting and harmony, about the experience of being in familiar and foreign places. When he's not listening to and composing music, Josh is writing code or reading contemporary philosophy. You can find his work at joshmiller.bandcamp.com.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
A good movie needs three things: the right equipment, the right story and the right actors. Everything else is just frosting on the proverbial cake. 

Producing a film can be tricky, for a multitude of reasons. Primarily, cinema is massively collaborative at the high levels, meaning you have to corral a sea of people at specific times and dates, and everyone needs to be committed and flexible. Paying people is a good way to keep them interested and involved, but passion is far superior and much more consistent. 

We Can Speak to the Dead won't suffer from any drawbacks of a big set because it won't have one. The bulk of the scenes will be carried by a single actor and the cinematography is going to be built around beautiful minimalism. The biggest challenge we will face producing the film is finding innovative ways to get around our small budget, but luckily, as a filmmakers who have been working on small budgets for years, we are ideally suited to the task.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: We Can Speak to the Dead officially in post!
updates.update_content:
Thanks to everyone who contributed to the principal photography of We Can Speak to the Dead. We are officially in post now, and will move on to editing, color grading and composition. 
A big round of applause to everyone who helped! Clips and set photos to follow :)
Richard

As of 4:30 p.m. today, We Can Speak to the Dead has officially been funded! Thanks to everyone who pledged and offered their support of the project, especially those who spread the word through social media. 
I'll keep updating this page as we move through the production process, detailing our progress and offering insights into the film's creative process. Anyone who pledged and is in the Portland area is encouraged to get in touch with us and drop by the set sometime! 
Thanks again and we'll update soon :)

campaign.story:
Listen to The March for the Future by Fang Moon: 
 A preview of what the final will look like!
Who are we?
James Fenner
Hi there, I'm James Fenner. I am an illustrator living in Portland, OR. I really love calm and reflective scenes that emphasize the internal. In the past I've worked with animation companies and various personal clients to bring ideas to life. I grew up in Michigan and moved to Oregon in 2009 to pursue schooling in Media Arts & Animation at the Art Institute of Portland and then I went on to study Illustration at PNCA.
_________________________________________________________________
Ben Luce
Hi I'm Ben Luce. I'm an animator in Portland, OR. I love animating 2D characters and effects with exaggerated and fluid motion. I'm originally from Connecticut, and I went to school at MICA in Baltimore, MD. I've freelanced for big clients like ESPN and Stevia, animated for Liz Miele's web series Damaged, and created Sinitus Tempo's music video Blue Alley Waltz. You can see examples on my website and my demo reel below.
What's the video about?
The video is a pastiche of 70s and 80s fantasy and scifi. Influences include Moebius, Heavy Metal, Ralph Bakshi films, 80s anime, and Fantastic Planet.
An evil wizard sends his minions across the desert to steal a magical crystal from a peaceful village. Without the crystal, the villagers' plants begin to wilt and die.
As the minions enter the wizard's castle to hand over the crystal, suddenly one of the other minions attacks him. The attacker is revealed to be the first hero in disguise. Our second hero jumps down from the rafters and joins in the fight. The story continues, but that's all for now...
How will you make the video?
Ben will animate the characters and effects using TVPaint to simulate cel animation techniques. Flash may also be used for some effects shots. The final video will be composited in After Effects to add extra motion, detail, and effects.
James will use Photoshop to design background images, like this one:
How long will it take?
We estimate that the final video will take 3 months to complete. We are shooting to complete the video around the beginning of November.
What's in it for me?
Not only will you get to be a part of an awesome animation project, but there are some great prizes to accompany your generosity (see our full prize list).
Where will the money go?
The funding will allow James and Ben to survive for a few months while working on something they enjoy. Fang Moon will get some great exposure and a piece that they can show off when introducing their brand, without having to fund it out of pocket. We're a small collection of creators looking to do what we love to do - create. With your help we will be able to accomplish that goal.
How did you all meet?
Lydia works at a local bar in Portland, Oregon. One night, Ben struck up a conversation and found out she was in a band. The topic of a music video arose, and the idea was born.
Ben and James were linked up through an event called "The Burst," put on by After Effects PDX, a local AE user group. Ben and James were given the theme of "float," and had one week to create up to a minute of animation. Their entry "Ghost Garbage" won first place.
After developing the idea with the band, Ben realized that he could use an extra hand on the project. James was interested, and so once again Ben and James are creating an animation together.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Luckily, we will be able to devote most if not all of our time to the project. However, even with this advantage, Murphy's Law comes into play. We will do our very best to overcome any setbacks or unforeseen circumstances that we run into.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
