campaign.story:
PUNK THE CAPITAL, STRAIGHT FROM WASHINGTON D.C.
When punk swept into Washington D.C. in the late 1970s, an explosive scene emerged with uncompromising attitudes and powerful new sounds. The ideas and music which grew out of that time continue to have a profound impact, resonating around the world. Filmmakers Paul Bishow and James Schneider are now pulling together their long-awaited documentary about that seminal moment: Punk the Capital, Straight from Washington D.C.
Punk the Capital takes us to the heart of why D.C. Punk has such staying power. For those who are already aware of this inspiring and influential story, Punk the Capital provides a fresh perspective and in-depth portrait of how D.C. Punk began, full of newly discovered footage and personal accounts, directed by two of D.C.'s veteran filmmakers. For those who do not know much about Washington D.C. culture or why D.C. Punk matters, this film will be a must-see.
Focusing on the period between 1976 and 1985, this documentary explores how D.C. Punk gained momentum and an affirmative, creative and constructive community emerged. At the core of the film is an artist's co-op called Madams Organ. It was a space of possibility, like punk itself, where the foundations of a remarkable scene took form. The Organ was a place where generations and musical genres mixed. It became the launching pad for the D.C. harDCore movement.
The project is born out of our love of this music, D.C. history, and our camaraderie with those who are in our film. It also is a product of the our friendship and collaborative work that began in D.C.'s Adams Morgan neighborhood over 20 years ago. It is fulfilling for us to bring our decades of experience to this hometown project, and to make a film about a subject that echoes our belief in filmmaking as a transformational art.
To explore the complexity of the period, we have conducted over 100 interviews with the key figures, collected more than 200 hours of rare archival footage, hundreds of photographs, flyers and zines. The film also features unseen Super-8 footage shot by a dozen different filmmakers. We envision this film to be a dynamic collage, drawing on a multitude of archives, past & present radio shows, concert audio and video recordings, interviews, and more.
Having collected nearly all the necessary pieces, we now need your help to put them all together and complete this film. Your contribution will help us cover the many expenses along the way, including: film lab transfers and preservation, editing, equipment rental and purchase, the final out of town interviews, sound mixing, and DVD production. Our goal amount has been calculated to cover these and other basic costs only. Reaching that goal amount will also make our work with D.C.-based charities become a reality (see "Beyond the Film" section below).
Your support to complete this vital documentary will also help to preserve and share these archives. For example, much of the collected Super-8 film is deteriorating and requires transfer to an archival format (see "Beyond the Film"). This is part of our larger effort to see this history preserved and in this regard, we have been working closely with the D.C. Public Library for the past year in establishing a D.C. Punk Archive. So your participation in this project is also about keeping this vital piece of history alive and accessable.
You can help us cross the finish line through your contribution and through your promotion of this campaign. Thank you for your support.
See below for additional info about the film and the filmmakers:
THE FILMMAKERS
Filmmakers James Schneider and Paul Bishow in 2003 beginning the project (photo Jeff Nelson)
James Schneider, a D.C. native who grew up in the skate and punk scenes of the mid 1980s, has spent the last 20 years directing and producing films and music videos. His filmography includes; “Blue is Beautiful” (1997) featuring Dischord recording artists The Make-Up, “The Band that Met the Sound Beneath” (2012) featuring the Chilean punk band Panico, and “Young Oceans of Cinema” (2011) about the French avant-garde filmmaker Jean Epstein. Schneider’s award-winning work has been screened at film festivals and museums around the world. For more info: www.jamesjune.info
Paul Bishow moved to D.C. in the late 1970s and was immediately drawn to the intimacy of the punk scene, with his Super-8 camera in hand. He has since made 8 feature length movies and dozens of short films, many with D.C. Punk bands. He was a founding member of the I am Eye Film Forum and managed the legendary art-house cinema, the Biograph Theater in Georgetown. His footage has appeared in many documentaries including Don Lett’s “Punk Attitude” (2005). Paul's brother Pat Bishow is also a film director, known for the El Frenetico series and Soultangler. For more info: www.paulbishow.com
MORE ABOUT THE FILM
The eyewitness account is the guiding perspective of this story. Just as Punk the Capital co-creator Paul Bishow was there in 1979 filming the punk explosion, the key figures who witnessed and participated in the rise of D.C. Punk/harDCore are all part of our film: Alec and Ian MacKaye, Henry Rollins, Jeff Nelson, Jello Biafra, Tesco Vee, Cynthia Connolly, Joe Keithley, Tim Kerr, Sharon Cheslow, and many more. Among other important aspects discussed by these figures are the beginnings of the Straight Edge movement, Dischord Records, and the evolution of a D.C. sound that would later carry on into bands like Fugazi. We also cover the interactions between D.C. Punk and another D.C. underground genre of the time, Go-Go. Aside from the music, many other aspects of the D.C. punk community are part of our film: for example photographers and 'zine publishers from the time such as Barbara Anne Rice and her 'zine Truly Needy.
D.C. Punk did not start in 1979 with harDCore. This documentary takes us back to the earlier generation who fought to open doors in a hesitant, if not resistant, government town. It is impossible to grasp what happened in D.C. circa 1980 without fully exploring what preceded that time. These pioneers created new sounds and a Do-It-Yourself approach by starting their own labels like Dacoit, Limp, and Doodley Squat. Punk the Capital includes bands such as the Slickee Boys, White Boy, Razz, and The Urban Verbs; figures like Skip Groff, Kim Kane, Martha Hull, Don Zientara and Howard Wuelfing; DJs like Xyra Harper and Steve Lorber from the rebellious local radio station WGTB; and early DC fanzine publishers such as Mary Leary (Infiltrator).
A behind-the-scenes discussion with Ian and Alec MacKaye about Paul Bishow's apartment, and his footage from 1979.
BEYOND THE FILM
D.C. Punk Activism
In the tradition of D.C. Punk non-profit work and benefit events dating back to 1980, arrangements are being made for 3 Washington D.C. non-profits to benefit from our film.  Details will be available in the next few months. These are the three non-profits:
Hungry For Music (D.C. Branch) is a charity organization that supports music education and cultural enrichment by acquiring and distributing quality musical instruments to underserved children.
Positive Force D.C. is an activist collective seeking radical social change, personal growth, and youth empowerment. They organize benefit and free concerts, art shows, film screenings, protests, and educational events while also doing direct work with people in need in Washington D.C..
Washington Peace Center is an anti-racist, grassroots, multi-issue organization working for peace, justice, and non-violent social change in the metropolitan Washington D.C. area since 1963.
Please go to the "Beyond the Film" section of our website for more information.
Preservation
Your contribution will help us to preserve and share a wide range of archives. These include film, video, audio, flyers, zines, photos and other ephemera.
Of particular interest is the recently unearthed Super-8 and 16mm footage collected from various sources. Some of this footage is rapidly degrading and needs immediate attention. Among the bands appearing in the footage are : Bad Brains, Untouchables, Faith, Teen Idles, Enzymes, Slickee Boys, Government Issue, Da Chumps, Half Japanese, Razz, Holy Rollers, Kingface, Trenchmouth and more. The footage also includes scenes of daily life, such as sequences fillmed in the Madams Organ Co-op and street life in D.C. circa 1979. 
D.C. Punk Archive
We  have been working closely with the D.C. Public Library's Washingtoniana Division on founding a D.C. Punk Archive. We will be transferring a large amount of the material from our documentary to this new collection. This archive is part of Washingtoniana's effort to preserve and celebrate D.C.'s rich music culture (Go-Go, Jazz, Folk, Garage...). It promises to be an accessible and instructive tool for the Nation's Capital and beyond.
THANK YOU 
Thank you for taking a moment to learn about our project. We appreciate your interest in our efforts to create a lasting and in-depth document of this transformative period in music history. Your enthusiasm and willingness to spread the word will help build the momentum needed to move this project forward. THANK YOU for your support. 
D.C. PUNK FILM COMMUNITY
Since we began this project circa 2000, other films on D.C. Punk have begun and we look forward to all of them. These documentaries are all quite different and we believe they will complement each other. The history of D.C. Punk is too big for one film. The unique focus of our project is on the transition from punk to harDCore in Washington, D.C., 1976 to 1985. The vast archives we have collected will contribute to the distinct perspective of this documentary, as it encapsulates the radical shift from 1970's culture into that of the 1980's.
Amongst the other films in the works are: a documentary about Positive Force D.C.; an HR (Bad Brains) documentary; an episode in a series for HBO featuring D.C.’s legendary Inner Ear Studio, directed by Dave Grohl; and Salad Days, which began in 2011, focusing on D.C. Punk of the mid-1980s.
Follow us on Facebook & Twitter for updates:
www.facebook.com/punkthecapitaldocumentary
www.twitter.com/PUNKTHECAPITAL
Check out our website for exclusive content from the film: 
www.dcpunkrockdoc.info
VERSION FRANCAISE DU CLIP (FRENCH VERSION)
PLAY

SINOPSIS, VERSIÓN EN ESPAÑOL (SPANISH VERSION)
PLAY

IMAGES
The Slickee Boys at WRIR with Dir. James Schneider, on one of many radio shows featured in film, 2011
Ian MacKaye and early harDCore flyer, 2005
Half Japanese, early 1980s Halloween bash, Super-8 freeze frame
Michael Hampton, Alec MacKaye & Chris Bald of Faith, Super-8 freeze frame, 1982
Skip Groff, of Yesterday and Today Records (store), Limp Records, 2011
Hanging in Henry Rollins' car, Super-8 freeze frame, circa 1980
Bad Brains at Madams Organ, Super-8 freeze frame, 1979
John Weiffenbach of Void and his canoe, 2012
Going through tons of Super-8 shot from the late 1970s to the mid 1980s in D.C.

REWARD IMAGES
"Are you ready? We are!" Fresh from the hallway of the legendary Inner Ear Studios: Poster/flyer for the 2nd Bad Brains show at Madams Organ, August 25th, 1979. Original 8.5" x 14" flyer comes framed from the collection of Don Zientara.
"Three Red X's, Two Red Lines" by DC area native, and 2004 Whitney Biennial participant Santiago Cucullu (limited ed. of 3). 16 x 22 unframed screen print signed by artist. Inspired by and made especially for Punk the Capital.
"Real Rock & Roll" Slickee Boys / White Boy two night show flyer (11 1/4" X 10 1/2") from the personal collection of Marshall Keith. Below is a video which talks more about that legendary show.
For the first time ever, Shepard Fairey / Obey's PUNK ICONS series is presented on ONE print, assembled especially for Punk the Capital. 18 x 24 inch Giclée Print individually signed by the artist, and part of an exclusive first run of only 10 copies.
Fugazi/Jem Cohen "Instrument" poster from NYU screening in 1999. Original 2-color Tribune ShowPrint 17"x27" on cardboard (from the personal collection of Brendan Canty)
Washington, D.C. Punk Tour with author and activist Mark Andersen. (See reward options #13 and #15)
Well loved 5 X 7 print of the front steps of Madams Organ artists co-op, 1980, by and from the collection of Paul Bishow.
Painting of the Madams Organ artists collective, 1979, by John Hagerhorst and Doug Goodhill (24"X32").
One of a kind 8 X 10 print of the Bad Brains, 1979. It was taken during the same photo shoot which produced the pic on their first 7 inch, "Pay to Cum". Pic was taken/made by Charley Davis and Paul Bishow.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This project is on solid footing to be completed as planned. It is always difficult to gauge how long the editing will last, so this is our main challenge. Even with the planned next 6 months of full time editing, such a large amount of footage presents a steep mountain to climb. The success of this campaign will ensure that the film is completed in a swift time frame and will be well circulated. In terms of content, the film itself has advanced to the point where we can assure that it will reflect how it is presented above.

campaign.story:
Founded in 2009 by 17-year-old Zuhal Sultan, a pianist in Baghdad, the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq is a group of 44 young musicians from across the country who overcome seemingly insurmountable barriers to make music together.
That the orchestra exists at all is astounding. Despite the lack of infrastructure and shortage of music teachers, musicians throughout Iraq have been recruited and auditioned each year via YouTube. In this short time, against all odds, the orchestra has gone from strength to strength.
Each year, the young Iraqi musicians gather for an annual summer camp where they receive their only musical instruction for the year from carefully selected international tutors. This three-week educational event culminates in a concert and to date, the orchestra has been invited to perform at the Beethovenfest in Bonn, Edinbugh Festival Fringe, London’s Queen Elisabeth Hall and Grand Theatre de Provence in France. These hugely successful concerts, attended by ambassadors, dignitaries and concert-goes alike, have been met with media approval and earned the orchestra well-deserved standing ovations. 
"It's vital that the orchestra gets out of Iraq and performs abroad so that they can relearn normality and take that back home with them to rebuild their culture." Music Director Paul MacAlindin, TEDx Koeln
This summer, the NYOI joins the Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra for three weeks of study in Illinois, followed by performances in Elgin, Chicago, and Washington, DC. The histories of America and Iraq are now deeply intertwined, though media distortion has ensured that each people has little idea of the other. Collaboration with players and tutors of the Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra, performing to American audiences and telling stories through music, is NYOI's effort to reach out to young Americans and share cultures.
Led by Music Director Paul MacAlindin, NYOI will perform Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto (featuring Angelia Cho, violin), Beethoven's Symphony No. 7, and two new works – one by Arab composer Amir ElSaffar and another by Kurdish composer Abdullah Jamal Sagirma. Unifying many different traditions of music and performance, NYOI offers another much-needed example of collaboration and harmony.  
"This is how I imagined the orchestra to be – for them to break all the barriers before them and communicate through music." Zuhal Sultan
Follow the #NYOIraq story on Tumblr, Twitter, and Facebook.  Watch and listen on YouTube and SoundCloud.
Contributions to the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq are processed through the Friends of the British Council USA, a 501(c)(3) organization, and are tax-deductible.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There is always risk with projects that have the capacity to do a great deal of good. 

The biggest challenge for the musicians of the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq is being an Iraqi musician at all, which represents a very real danger in the lives of these artists. But the orchestra has broken through new barriers each year, successfully securing the visas, funding, and management required to perform and grow together. 

Many of those challenges for this year's tour have already been solved, through in-kind support from the Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra, the Arts Center at Elgin Community College, Northern Illinois University, and a number of businesses, individuals, and foundations in the U.S. Though the total cost of this year's tour is more than $400,000, another $40,000 is needed for insurance, travel, and accommodations.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

National Youth Orchestra of Iraq
First created · 0 backed
Called "the world's bravest orchestra," the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq is a group of 44 Iraqi musicians who travel the world to study...See more

updates.update_content:
We regretfully announce that we have cancelled our U.S. tour scheduled for this August. Instability in Iraq has made it impossible for orchestra members to complete the visa process that would allow them to travel, though thankfully all NYOI musicians are currently safe.
As we look toward the summer of 2015, we are so grateful for all the support shown to us in the U.S. so far.  We're looking forward to continuing our partnership with Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra in the future, and we encourage everyone to stay up to date with both orchestras by connecting on Facebook and Twitter.

updates.update_userinfo: Your support means the world to us.

updates.update_content:
Thank you to the support of 85 incredible backers who have pledged more than $10,000 to the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq!
As you know, Iraq has been plunged into a state of unrest in the last several days, and many of our plans and communications have been delayed.  (That's why it's been a little quiet on our end.)  But NYOI's music and message are more important now than ever before.  In spite of chaos and violence, the orchestra plays on.

updates.update_userinfo: Premiere concerts announced, with 10 days left on Kickstarter!

updates.update_content: With the first half of the campaign behind us (that's right, only 20 days to go), we have surpassed our first small milestone: 57 backers have pledged more than $5,000 to NYOI's U.S. tour.  We send our heartfelt thanks to our supporters across the U.S. and the world.

campaign.story:
Purpose: to raise funds for the Restoration and Preservation -- already in progress -- of the World's Longest Graphic Novel: the 6,000-page, 16-volume CEREBUS (1977 to 2004). 
 Hi! I'm Dave Sim.  I'm making the attempt to keep CEREBUS going 10 years after completion. A perhaps insurmountable uphill struggle but we won't know "yes" or "no" for sure for a while yet.
I needed to have an idea of how many people are willing to commit $79 to assist in that Restoration and Preservation so I've been accepting reservations for CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER ONE (signed and numbered edition ONLY available here on Kickstarter) from the 2012 Kickstarter partners and Tim W's A Moment of Cerebus website (momentofcerebus.blogspot.com) this past week.  Today, April 30th (Happy Birthday, Jeff Seiler! who has reserved #301) as I'm typing this, we're at 114 people.  80 from Kickstarter and 34 from A Moment of Cerebus. 
The good news is, even if all of those people actually come through, this will be the RAREST CEREBUS NUMBER ONE in history, way, way WAY below the sales of 2,000 copies on CEREBUS No.1 (1977)!  
Bottom line, we had a thoroughly botched (George and Sean are still woking actively to "unbotch" it) restoration of the CEREBUS and HIGH SOCIETY volumes and now have to pay off the printer to get back to Square One.  Around $15,000 to $20,000 depending on what they'll settle for. So, the not-so-good news is even if everyone who has reserved a number actually participates, once you deduct all of the expenses, the 114 copies will pay only about one quarter of the printing bill.  
I'm willing to keep going with this.  I know CEREBUS is important to those 114 people, so I'm willing to do CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER TWO, NUMBER THREE, NUMBER FOUR, NUMBER FIVE...whatever it takes to get the printing bill paid off.  And then start getting quotes from other printers and getting sample signatures printed, to make sure future CEREBUS fans are getting the best printed trade paperbacks possible. 
But, you have to admit that it's an uphill struggle that I don't think the word "insurmountable" understates.  If we can't do it, we can't do it. OR if it takes a year or two of quarterly Kickstarter campaigns with fewer and fewer people pledging each time...well, at least all of those people will have the absolute rarest LAST CEREBUS ARCHIVE signed and numbered printing. :)  
That's why I selected a relatively low but realistic target of $800.  I'll keep doing this even if we get down to the Last Ten Cerebus fans and it takes a decade or more to get that printing bill paid off. 
This is what we're going to be trying to do over the course of the next thirty days.   
TARGET: $800 
PLEDGE ITEM: $79 plus postage/shipping costs to your region. (Please choose the reward that MATCHES your country with your carrier choice). Note: for shipments within Canada, shipping costs have been added to the $79 due to the way that Kickstarter handles domestic shipping. They are priced at $95 and $98, BUT that includes the shipping costs. For all other countries, the cost will show as $79 and there will be a shipping charge added (per the amount listed in the Reward Item text) at time of payment. Bottom line: the cost to anyone on the globe is $79 CAD PLUS shipping to your address with a choice of two (or more) carriers and/or service levels.
CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER ONE
A FOLIO OF THE TEN EARLIEST PAGES IN THE CEREBUS ARCHIVE WITH COMMENTARY BY DAVE SIM
________________________________________________________
1. PARODY OF FRANK FRAZETTA'S CONAN BERSERKER PAPERBACK COVER
1. PARODY OF FRANK FRAZETTA'S CONAN BERSERKER PAPERBACK COVER
Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary: 
"This is the earliest piece of published CEREBUS artwork in the Cerebus Archive, measuring 11.5 x 17.5 inches.The idea had been to have a third item to sell on our convention table in Toronto along with CEREBUS No.1 and the 'just published' No.2"… "Gaelic borders are really a test of artistic focus and patience"…"I wanted to translate Frazetta's oil paint effects into Barry Windsor-Smith pen lines"…"if you close off solutions to your rendering and printing problems…and ignore what your solutions are going to result in, you're going to end up with a very amateurish finished product."
YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
2, 3, 4, 5 "PASSAGE" pages 3, 4, 5 and 6
2. "PASSAGE" page 3
3. "PASSAGE" page 4
4. "PASSAGE" page 5
5. "PASSAGE" page 6
Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary:
"…marks the second time that Cerebus wore his idiosyncratic black vest (an idea I got from the black leather vest that was one of Gene Day's most frequently worn items of clothing: influencing me personally and creatively, I bought a vest just like it which I still own even though I haven't worn it for years"…"I didn't have to focus on what parts of the figures and backgrounds should be done with brush"…"There's also some use of the Hunt 102 in the captain's eyebrow at the extreme right, his beard in the bottom right corner (page 5 panel 6)"…"how much of the artwork could I do with rapidographs and just filling in solid black? Or, put another way, how much did I have to do with the Hunt 102 to make it look as if the whole page was done with the Hunt 102?"…"How do you prove this many years later that something is your property when the other person has 'owned' it for a couple of decades?" 
YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
6. CEREBUS THE HOLOGRAM PENDENT Inside Back Cover advertisement - CEREBUS No.12 to 25
6. CEREBUS THE HOLOGRAM PENDENT
Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary:
"Of course when you said 'hologram' what everyone pictured was hologram projection, a feature of late 1970s science fiction movies, not fuzzy, yellow, glowing little sculptures that didn't move and were only visible within a narrow sight window"…"it's a large Cerebus, probably, the largest I had drawn to that point"…"you'll also notice that Cerebus' top medallion has been patched.  When I was peeling off the excess tone, half the medallion came with it." 
YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED IN WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
7. CEREBUS No.12 page 5
7. CEREBUS No.12 page 5
  Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary:
"Marshall Rogers had persuaded me that I needed to render Cerebus more -- up to issue 10 or so, my idea had been to keep Cerebus looking like an animation cel with just a thin line"…"In retrospect, he was wrong: what I needed was a #2 or #3. But, even there, I soured on the idea of using a brush because they were so hard to maintain"…"Duo Shade is illustration board that is pre-printed with two shades of grey, a light and a dark.  You can see that the background colour of the page is a sort of greenish-yellow"…"You can't just blob the developer on there as if you're water-colouring and blot up the excess and expect that it's going to reproduce properly"…"meant that I couldn't go in close enough to the edge of the bubbles because the developer would 'pool' in the tiny areas and go too dark." 
YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED IN WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
8. CEREBUS No.18 page 7
8. CEREBUS No.18 page 7
  Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary:

"I had graduated from the strict 'two widths of rapidograph and filling in solid black with a brush' to actually rendering with the #4 brush Marshall Rogers had suggested.  It was extremely awkward"…"On this page, the cross-hatched backgrounds are all done with a broken-in Hunt 102.  The only remaining parts that aren't #4 brush are: panel 1: Lord Julius' face (the outline done with a broken-in Hunt 102 and the eyes, cheeks, nose, eyebrows and moustache with a new Hunt 102)"…"the shadow on the underside of the chin (which you can only see with the level of detail you're getting here)"…"I've whited out Lord Gorce's hair on the left and re-rendered the feathered sheen with a broken-in Hunt 102"  

YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED IN WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
9. CEREBUS No.21 page 11
9. CEREBUS No.21 page 11
  Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary:

"I used what appeared to be a much finer brush because the areas of solid black are much more sharply rendered"…"a new Hunt 102 for pretty much everything else.  Instead of getting an illusion of detail from your peripheral vision, you actually get a detailed panel"…"The detail in the mask and the eyes -- obviously done with a Brand New Hunt 102 -- is pretty much unheard of in the book"… "the receding vertical lines at the top of the weird building in the foreground aren't really following the perspective lines and the vertical lines below the shadowed area -- rendered with a broken-in Hunt 102 -- are too coarse so they're interfering with the flying hat"

YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED IN WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
10. CEREBUS No.22 page 19
10. CEREBUS No.22 page 19
Excerpts from Dave Sim's commentary:
"Apart from that, structurally, it's a very good page. The two Cerebus figures in panels 1 and 2 have a perfect density to their outlines and internal rendering which you can see more clearly at 'full size'"…"The pen lines in the snow and on Weisshaupt's stocking in panel 1 actually look professional"…"The fact that the vertical lines I used to render the bricks and the solid black on the page and the fine lines are in perfect balance is still exceptional when it comes to my work"… 
YOU CAN READ THIS ENTIRE COMMENTARY IN THE "NOTES" INCLUDED IN WITH EACH FOLIO
________________________________________________________
CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER ONE folio will be signed and numbered based on the final number of copies pledged for when the one-month Kickstarter campaign has ended.  The "500 available" is a very unlikely upper maximum number. All proceeds will go towards the Restoration and Preservation of the CEREBUS and HIGH SOCIETY volumes.  Additional funds (if any) will go towards the Restoration and Preservation of future volumes, starting with the 1200-page CHURCH & STATE and READS.

There will be a new Kickstarter campaign every quarter for each successive release of a CEREBUS ARCHIVE FOLIO:

CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER TWO - FALL, 2014
    The Earliest 10 pages of HIGH SOCIETY in the Cerebus Archive

CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER THREE - WINTER 2014-15
     The Earliest 10 pages of CHURCH & STATE I in the Cerebus Archive

CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER FOUR - SPRING 2015
     The Earliest 10 pages of CHURCH & STATE II in the Cerebus Archive

CEREBUS ARCHIVE NUMBER FIVE - SUMMER 2015
      The Earliest 10 pages of JAKA'S STORY in the Cerebus Archive

You can retain your same "signed and numbered" number for each Folio by pledging in each quarterly campaign.   

SHIPPING COSTS:
As opposed to the first Kickstarter campaign which ended up losing roughly $8,000 because of shipping costs, shipping costs will be added to each pledge on top of the $79.  These are the available shipping methods and associated costs:

AUSTRALIA (and ASIA):
CANADA:
USA:
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Well, I learned a lot from the HIGH SOCIETY AUDIO DIGITAL Kickstarter campaign in 2012 which took in $64,000 and cost all of that and about $5,000 to $8,000 of my own money because it was so badly planned, particularly International shipping costs (90% of the problem). 

It was also a bad idea to have someone running it who already had a full-time job so even though the campaign ended in June, by December all of the money was gone and only about two-thirds of the items had shipped. I ended up getting three HUGE cartons of pledge items back from the fulfillment guy in March of 2013 that I had thought had all shipped three months before and had to spend three months FULL time finding out who hadn't gotten what and shipping them what was missing. All at International priority postal rates that ranged from $45 to $75 depending on the destination. 

That's why this time there is only the one item, everything has been costed out, packaging, shipping, weight, International, US and structured in such a way that all of the pledge items will be shipping within sixty days of the end of the campaign.

I'll tackle any setback this time the way I tackled them last time: fixing any problem that comes up as soon as I'm aware of it. 

Only this time, with a full-time fulfillment guy who will be keeping me updated on a daily basis.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Um...did you get the birthday card I sent yet? Did you like it? Are you okay with me scanning it and posting it on Facebook for the whole world to see (not that you could stop me...) Ooh, FOLLOW-UP: Shouldn't you be drawing the Strange Death of Alex Raymond?

Okay, another one: Since AMOC has been posting those old FC reproduction covers, it occurred to me for the first time while looking at the Frazetta recreation: Did you get any flack from Marvel over doing the Wolveroach character (in multiples) again so many years after the "cease and desist" letter from Shooter? Or do you figure they just didn't see it, since it was a mag not a comic, or that they just didn't care after all those years?

Ok, Dave, I'll bite. A question about. . .anything? Alright: It is Thursday afternoon. I've been moving since around 8 am this morning until about half an hour ago when I took a break to come to the library. More moving tonight, but with help for the heavy stuff. As you know, I walk with a cane and I get to move down from the third story to the ground floor. So, alone, I spent about six hours carrying the small stuff ONE ITEM AT A TIME in my left hand, using the right one to lean on the staircase railings. I also was accosted by an old woman (who bore a not-unstriking resemblance to Mrs. Henrot-Gutch) who was complaining repeatedly "when are you going to be done because you're not supposed to block the doors in the staircase open or for so long". I also yakked (seriously ralphed) five times last night after having had way too much coffee yesterday morning. Got three hours sleep last night. I have to be out by noon Saturday and that includes the time for the cleaners to come in. So my question to you is: Do you think I will survive this move and receive and enjoy my two Cerebus Archive #1 portfolios? Inquiring minds (or one such) want to know. Thanks for taking the time. See you Saturday afternoon to let you know how it turns out (or not).
And given the issues with getting those books back into print, would you tell young Dave Sim (if you went back in a time machine to '77) not to bother with the tone? ;)
Hi Dave, just a quick note to congratulate you guys on another successful Kickstarter. I look forward to seeing the prints! -Rafer.
Just pledged! As a Kitchener native I'm excited to support a local legend. Cerebus brings back some awesome memories of high-school in 1980s KW! Good luck with future campaigns ... count me in!

I love seeing Cerebus in the "modern" world, like the few spots in the Guide to Publishing, or the pics of him in his hockey gear...any chance of us ever seeing him in the "real" world for 8 pages or so? After Strange Death, naturally. Thanks, Jim

Have you ever considered converting the Cerebus setting to the world of pen and paper Role Playing Games like Dungeons and Dragons? I think the world would fit right in a game setting, especially the first third of the story.

I live right next to Westport CT and just wanted to let you know that if you need anything in the way of research from the area (photos or what-have-you), for The Strange Death, I'd be more than happy to oblige.

Hey Dave, thanks for doing this! Are there any regrets storyline-wise, that Cerebus took, that looking back on it so many years later you wished you hadn't taken with the book? Not what you would do differently now, just wondering if there any paths you would've changed direction on? Thanks again!
What books, poems, essays, films, and albums should I find to better appreciate/understand Cerebus?
Yeah, i didn't realise it was live either. I have pledged for one portfolio (EU, no tracking) and a set of 4 book plates. I only have 4 of the phone books, so thats enough.

I too must confess... after obtaining my OWN archive reserve number, I almost forgot to check on the project itself! (I don't recall receiving any sort of reminder email, but maybe I missed it.) Anyway, I finally did remember to send in my first deposit. By the way, the project seems to be going great so far. There is now almost $24,000 pledged, with still a week to go! Not too shabby, considering the original goal was only $800! Good luck the rest of the way.

Thanks for the email about this being live...while I was Johnny on the spot to get the reserve number (17), I completely forgot the project was underway....terrible how deliriums wax and wane. Always a Sim supporter, got my cash in! Good turn out so far!
Thanks for any guidance! -Bill

In response to James' comment and to try to clarify, Dave indeed did sell many pages of early original artwork. I don't know if he has all of the art from #1 left, but I would suspect not. In fact, Dave noted that he once sold every page of an issue (probably not #1) for about $10 per page so he could buy some primo weed. Back in his smoking days, that is. As the great Yogi Berra may or may not have once (or more often) said, "You could look it up."
Will these been on heavy card stock or will this be a fairly light paper?
Mike

For some reason I didn't back until today but I did secure a good number back in April. I would totally choose the house tour if the dates went out further. I'm stuck in Thule, Greenland for a year starting in July(military).
Jim
Whoops! I should have said non super hero graphic novels.
Puma Blues and Journey were both on the list. Not bad bad for Aardvark-Vanaheim, who originally published those books.

A copy of this portfolio has been uploaded onto Flickr and can be seen at https://www.flickr.com/photos/8117508@N08/sets/72157600160103014. Don't know how Flickr user "quwanjew," who posted the images, got a copy, if they're all in the possession of the Gene Day Estate. On the other hand, it was 25 years ago that Sim wrote his comments, and it's possible that the estate may have sold some, or all, of its copies since then.
That's 114. Interested to see where we go from here.

I don't think I can frame everything, so my thinking is to purchase a photo album and put each print and commentary page or pages to display as an archive where anyone can flip through without getting any finger prints on them.

John, for those who reserved a specific number (and that reservation was confirmed by you via email), how will that request and the actual paid backing be synced? Is this to be done on some later confirmation or some other mechanism? Thanks in advance for response or guidance, Bill
So maybe something like this can be worked out for this campaign?
However what does "earliest 10 pages" mean? These are not the first 10 pages of issue #1?
I excited as heck to back this endeavor. I'll be back for all of the volumes. Best wishes, Mr. Sim.
Thanks for doing this kickstarter. I am very excited to support the cause and hope you are hugely successful with this!
Best of luck to you, Dave. I think you'll do a lot better than you expect (at least I hope so)!
George
Hi, good luck with all this! Is there a way to reserve a particular number for these? Thanks guys.

campaign.story:
DID YOU MISS OUR KICKSTARTER? It's not too late to support us and try our Beta test! Please visit us at storium.com for more information.
4/8/14: WE DID IT! With the help of our incredible backers, we have unlocked every stretch goal, funded a staggering 60 worlds, and reached 1000% of our original funding target. This has been an incredible campaign and we are deeply grateful for the support we've received.
(Are you a backer looking for your Beta invite? Please see the first FAQ at the bottom of this page — the info you need is there!)
“Storium is everything I never knew I always wanted in a game.” — Eve Jacob, playtester
Stories are part of what makes us human. They’re all around us, from books and movies to TV and video games. Experiencing a good story can be one of life’s great pleasures. But telling your own can be even more fun!
That’s why we’ve devoted the last year of our lives to creating Storium, the online storytelling game. We’ve been playtesting an early version for months with hundreds of people. The feedback has been amazing, and we’re ready to bring Storium to the public. We need your help to make it happen.
Storium is a web-based online game that you play with friends. It works by turning writing into a multiplayer game. With just your computer, tablet, or smartphone, you can choose from a library of imaginary worlds to play in, or build your own. You create your story’s characters and decide what happens to them. You can tell any kind of story with Storium. The only limit is your imagination.
Storium uses familiar game concepts inspired by card games, role-playing games, video games, and more. In each Storium game, one player is the narrator, and everyone else takes on the role of a character in the story. The narrator creates dramatic challenges for the other players to overcome. In doing so, they move the story forward in a new direction. Everyone gets their turn at telling the story.
“Story and Game had a baby, and it’s Storium. This is vital stuff, equal parts revolutionary and fundamental — giving the old ways of storytelling a major digital upgrade.”— Chuck Wendig, novelist and screenwriter
The following three-minute video gives you a glimpse of our current beta playtest:
What makes Storium special?
Total freedom: You decide what happens in your story.
Multiplayer: Write and play with your friends, online.
Asynchronous: Play at your own pace.
Worlds: Pre-made playsets that help you tell stories in different settings and styles.
Something for everyone: You can tell any kind of story you want!
“Storium is one of the most fascinating systems I’ve ever used to facilitate games, and it’s helped me fall in love with storytelling all over again.”– Lillian Cohen-Moore, playtester
This campaign funds the work that’s needed to launch Storium to the general public. That means:
1. Worlds for you to play in
Storium needs a wider library of what we call worlds. Each world is a complete playset that gives you all the tools you need to play a game in a certain style or fictional setting. This includes virtual playing cards that drive gameplay, ideas for stories, pre-made characters, and backstory. We’ve assembled an award-winning group of novelists, game designers, storytellers, and artists to create these worlds. Some worlds are wholly new, while others are adaptations of worlds you’ll recognize.
2. Important features
There are key features that Storium still needs. Your support will help us build them. This list is subject to change based on prioritization and technical feasibility, but here are a few of the examples we are considering:
Real-time play: Chat and play live with your friends when they’re online.
Shared narration: Give everyone in your game a chance to be the narrator.
Parallel storytelling: Play out two scenes at the same time with different characters.
Improved support for tablets and smartphones: Play using interfaces created specifically for your mobile device.
3. Technology and team
Operating an online service like Storium can be a labor-intensive and expensive task. While it's easy to use and play, behind the scenes Storium is a complex piece of engineering. It requires dedicated, ongoing developer attention. We also have to pay for servers, storage, and a number of underlying services upon which the system relies. As Storium grows, these costs increase. 

We’ve been working full-time on Storium without pay for over a year now. That’s how much this project means to us. We've set our target goal as low as possible, but anything we raise beyond that helps ensure that as Storium grows and evolves, we’ll be able to keep up by investing in the technology and people we need.

“Storium revolutionizes storytelling not by new bells and whistles but by returning it to its most pure form in this most complex of ages — dynamic characters and people telling evocative and passionate stories.” — John Adamus, playtester



Here's a visual overview of the rewards we're offering!
And here are more details about a few of the more popular rewards:
Beta player
Every backer at the BETA PLAYER ($10) level gets instant access to our current beta test of Storium. You’ll find an invitation URL in campaign update #1 (backers only). This URL enables you to immediately sign-up, start a game, and invite your friends to play with you.

Please bear in mind that this is an early test version of Storium. We expect it to change and grow quite a bit before the public launch. As a beta player, we welcome your feedback. There’s a “Give feedback” button at the top of every page that goes to a built-in playtesters-only feedback system.

Member
When it launches to the public, Storium will have a modest annual membership fee of $25 per year — the equivalent of just $2 per month. Becoming a backer at the MEMBER ($20) level gets you your first year of Storium membership (starting on the date we launch publicly) for just $20.

Members will also be granted a special ability when Storium launches publicly: the use of our forthcoming World Creator tools to build their own Storium worlds and share them with the Storium community.

(By the way, there will always be a free version of Storium — and it will be the full game, not a demo version. You’ll be able to play up to three games, with full functionality, before you have to pay any membership fee!)

We want to grow Storium into a sustainable business, and we want to do it without plastering the game with advertisements. Our membership fee will help make that possible.

The Deal
Our campaign starts by funding ten worlds, but we have dozens more in the works from a wide array of award-winning creators. Every backer at THE DEAL ($40) level will get a year of Storium membership, plus early and ongoing access to every world that we fund through this Kickstarter. This means you'll always be able to play games in these worlds, regardless of whatever they end up costing in the future.

(When Storium launches publicly, many of our Kickstarter worlds will have a small fee for usage. Much like how Apple's App Store works, Storium world creators will have the option of charging app-like prices for their worlds. We will then pass on the majority of the proceeds to the world's creator! We hope this will become great new way for players and fans alike to support the authors and designers whose work they love.)

"I work nights and weekends and haven’t been able to game with my friends in years. Storium is letting me play again, and the system they’ve built is incredibly cool." — Brian White, playtester
   Unlocks at $250,000
CHAMPIONS UNIVERSE — Enter a world of amazing, super-powered adventure. Developed by dozens of talented creators for more than thirty years, the Champions Universe lets you tell any sort of superhero story you want. Patrol the high-tech streets of Millennium City or the shadowy alleys of Vibora Bay, fight the mighty Grond or the madcap Foxbat, and stop Dr. Destroyer from conquering the world! (Based on the core setting of the Champions Online MMO from Cryptic Studios and the Champions RPG from Hero Games.) (Learn more)
This campaign has already unlocked numerous features and 59 worlds by award-winning creators, with more to come!
Storium is being built by a small but talented and dedicated team. We believe that technology can help unlock human creativity, and Storium is our effort to do just that. Between us, we have many years of experience spanning startups, engineering, product design, game design, writing, film, art direction, transmedia and more.
1. Stephen Hood: Co-founder and product lead. Stephen has spent his entire career working in technology, including stints at Yahoo and social bookmarking pioneer Delicious, where he first worked with Josh. Stephen is an avid reader and a life-long player of video and role-playing games. Storium began with an idea and a prototype that Stephen built over a year ago.
2. Josh Whiting: Co-founder and engineering lead. Josh has also spent his entire career working on technology, specifically as an engineer and architect. He was a senior engineer at Craigslist, and also worked with Stephen at Delicious. In his spare time he is a composer of electronic music.
3. Will Hindmarch: Lead game designer and head writer. Will's extensive résumé spans tabletop gaming, video games, fiction and beyond. He’s worked on a number of influential games and projects including Vampire: The Requiem, the Dragon Age RPG, Lord of the Rings Online, Always/Never/Now, and Project: Dark. Will's game design expertise and love of writing are at the heart of Storium.
4. J.C. Hutchins: Advisor and award-winning transmedia storyteller. J.C. is well-known for his acclaimed 7th Son series of thriller novels. He also co-wrote Personal Effects: Dark Art with Jordan Weisman (of Shadowrun fame). He has worked on major transmedia projects for Cinemax, A&E, Discovery, and many others. His new serialized fiction project The 33 is in production now.
5. Mur Lafferty: Advisor, Campbell-winning novelist, and podcaster. Mur is an acclaimed author who has won rave reviews for her novels The Shambling Guide to New York CIty and Ghost Train to New Orleans. She has recorded over 300 episodes of her Parsec Award-winning podcast series, I Should Be Writing.
6. Chuck Wendig: Advisor, Campbell-nominated novelist, Emmy-nominated screenwriter, and widely-followed blogger. Chuck is known for his popular novels, including the acclaimed Miriam Black series, the genre-bending Blue Blazes, the young adult novel Under The Empyrean Sky and many other works.
Video credits
Filmmaker: Erik Scanlon
Music: "A Promise" by D.P. Kaufman
Special thanks to the city of Carmel, CA
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The foundation of Storium has already been built and tested extensively. The game is real, and it works. We have the knowledge and skills needed to complete the job. We are also fully committed to the task and do not foresee a situation — short of a confluence of major, unplanned life events — that would derail our efforts.

Our founding team has a combined 25 years of experience with building online products and managing startups, and they have worked together for over 8 years. We are an effective team and are confident we can overcome problems that might waylay a less experienced group.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hi everyone —
I’m happy to announce the release of another addition to our library of backer worlds!

Hi everyone — 
Today we have another world to announce. And I'm particularly excited about this one because it was written by one of our backers!

Today I have the pleasure of announcing the release of another new Storium world!
7th Sea: Trouble in Avalon is adapted from the popular 7th Sea roleplaying game by John Wick Presents.

TL;DR: we’re getting ready to kick-off a beta pilot for StoriumEdu, our new education-oriented version of Storium. As Kickstarter backers you’re the first to hear about it.

updates.update_userinfo: StoriumEdu beta coming soon -- join the waiting list!
updates.update_content:
Hi again, everyone —
As promised, I'm back today to announce the roll-out of another Kickstarter world: Emerald City Adventures!

Hi everyone —
I'm happy to share the news that we've just rolled-out two new Storium worlds! Both of these worlds are part of our Kickstarter-funded world library and are available immediately to backers at "THE DEAL" level and higher.
Brancliff Manor

updates.update_userinfo: Two new worlds, with more to come
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone —
Following on the heels of our recent launch of two new Storium worlds I have more good news to share today, this time about our plans for an educational version of Storium.
As you may recall, one of our stretch goals for this campaign was a project we called “Storium for Schools.” Prompted by an outpouring of interest from backers, we committed to building a version of Storium tailored for teacher and student use. We even did some which helped us learn more about teachers’ needs and how Storium could best meet them.

updates.update_userinfo: Free membership extensions for backers, and a look back at our first year
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone —

I expect to have several pieces of good news and progress to share with you over the next few days. Today, I’m happy to start by reporting that we’ve just unveiled two more of our planned Kickstarter worlds!
In Nomine

comments.content: My apologies for my recent outburst. I sent an email to cancel my membership and believed (incorrectly) that kickstarter backers wouldn't be receiving refunds. I apologize for not making my statement through business channels and posting a public complaint without clarify my position first. I simply don't wish to use storium and I have no further complaints against the company.

THANKS A TON STEPHEN HOOD(WINK)! I hope you enjoy keeping the money you took from everyone since this is kick starter and we didn't (technically) pay you directly, even though you still offer refunds, but KICKSTARTER isn't a store
"Have no intention of playing Storium anymore."
So Storium wants me to fill out a survey, but I don't actually see it here on this page! I'm not sure where to go to fill this out :C
Storium + 7th Sea= wow

Sorry i freaked out, the website was misleading. It said "One year of Storium membership (starting with our public launch) at a discounted rate" making me think i still had to pay. Thanks for clearing that up.

@creator I am a little upset here, i feel like i was lied to. When i backed this project i thought i would get early access to the beta and a free year when it launched. Now you changed it on us and we still have to pay for something we already paid for? This "Discount for backers" is a slap in the face!
My old gaming friends and I no longer live near each other, but with this we had a blast making a wonderfully interactive story together! Thanks.
-A
Okay, thank you for that clarification.

I have a question of clarification. The discounted rate for backers... is that for the first year the site is up only or is it indefinitely? It feels unclear to me whether you can buy discounted yearly membership indefinitely or if it is only discounted that first year the site is up.
Gotta say that I am LOVING Storium so far! Keep up the great work. If anyone wants to see my profile, I'm Threemoons over there also.
Thank you, Josh! Get well soon!
Oooh!! Sunday sounds great!! Wheee!!
Gamma! Gamma! Gamma!
When Gamma arrives, if I have a game started, will players be able to make a second character mid-game or only at the start?
"would fit"
Has the Frame size for the Storium Banner Image changed? I was trying to generate a custom world and none of the banner photos i downloaded would into the box.

I was just wondering Stephen one of the most annoying processes I found with the whole creation of storiums or rps is making the cards, especially strengths and weaknessesd have you thought about implementing a storing process so if you feel you will use cards you made before in another game you can transfer them to a new game?
I just wanted to say that I've gotten more utility and hours of fun out of the beta than any other Kickstarter I've funded this year. That's all. Carry on.
Hey I was just wondering how much longer it will be until the Storium forums are up and running?

It would be a cool idea if you could allow the option to make moves that only some players can see, if you are doing a story where you are playing against each other it would be fun that you can hide what you are doing from the other player and it's only revealed to everyone when the scene has been finished.
http://rpg.drivethrustuff.com/product/84298/De-Profundis-Second-Edition
I'm impressed. Very much so.

I have a question/suggestion/request. When the backed worlds get rolled out, will it be possible to import cards from those stories into already existent games? I have a couple in progress that I think are pretty close to some of the unlocked worlds, I'd very much like to be able to import those assets into ongoing stories rather than have to start something from scratch.

At the VERY least a monthly newsletter showing us you guys are still hard at work (not that we doubt it, but it's cool to see what the devs are up to and that they are dedicated to helping the project grow and thrive).

@stephen Why not have the characters be sticky so that they are easily accessible? The left hand side of the page is just empty real-estate. Why not have the notifications be similar to what Facebook does and stick them up on the top-sticky bar. Then you could also include the read/unread feature so it would be easier to navigate through notifications.

@stephen the challenges are handled "overall" on top and "at that point" in any move. Why not the same for portraits? If clarity is required, use an indicator such as font color or italics or anything similar.
Ah! I see. That makes sense. Thank you for clarifying that.

As for the feedback button on Storium itself...that thing is the most inefficient way to suggest something I have ever seen. I had so much trouble navigating it that it made me forget about wanting to suggest something. I've noticed that that Stephen was great about listening to comments and suggestions here, so I've been putting them here. It's just a lot easier, and they still see it.

Brian, I don't think you understood me. Rather than hunting through the dozens of game events to find the character submission, why can't I click on the character name in the game edit page? I can retire them that way, why can't I ask for revisions that way?

@Garth Storium makes a clear distinction between *editing* the game and *playing* the game. I think this sets the mode quite nicely. Perhaps there is room for improvement, but merging the two--and thus blurring the distinction--is probably not a good idea.

Also, as a narrator, apparently the only way to approve a character or ask for revisions is by clicking on the event 'X has submitted a character'. Why, oh why, can't we do this from the game page itself?
Thanks!
If we find what appears to be a bug, what's the best way to notify your team?
http://reddit.com/r/storium

Is there a forum or central communications hub for Storium? It seems like trying to get a game together without one can be difficult, especially without set players in mind. Basically you just have to make a game and dangle it out there, hoping enough people like it to make it work.
Maybe each game can have settings for narrator control - the relatively non-intrusive default setting, and other settings that give more power to alter cards, etc.
Given that x5 is the default setting for handing out stacks, this can lead to problems for people who don't define their goals flexibly enough. A lot can change in five scenes.

When we play such a card, we should have the option to pick from any currently existing Strength or Weakness (as applicable) in the game: the ones available at character creation, ones made up by people when they make their characters, and the Wilds everyone else has made up and played. And if none of those suit, we could then go ahead and make our own, which gets added to the pool for the next person.

@chris: You mean forcing a player to lose his card somehow, or having a character/obstruction requiring a certain card? Would be cool if they forgot something in a cave and then have the players shout "fuuuu" when they require a certain card that they cant get anymore...

In a pen and paper RPG, the GM can change pretty much anything at any time, but knows that if he does too much he'll lose his players. I think we should have the option of more control in our Storium games, too.

It'd be nice if that started automatically once Players submit their Character. Right now, for example, if I, as Narrator, send a Character back for revision, there's not a great way to tell them anything else until they resubmit. I'd like to allow that to be more of a collaborative dialog rather than a formal review process. I seem to have afterthoughts that I'd like to pass along, or things that would help their characters tie in more tightly with the others. I hope that makes sense!
(An incredibly belated) Congrats on over 1000% of your goal! What an incredible event! I know you guys are going to do so much good, especially with the school stretch goal. High fives for everyone!
Cheers, and thanks for the great work so far!
This is so exciting. This game is going to be so awesome, and I love that so many sci-fi and fantasy authors have participated!
I'm thinking it'll be important to have them playtested a bit before you ask the professional writers to start making their 60 worlds. If not in the Beta, then maybe Gamma?

And another thing (i just thought about) is giving people some sort of "timer" (set by the narrator) before you can spam the "lag" button... I have 2 stories now where I dont know if I should press the button or not, and how long I should wait.

@Stephen: I have been around now for (i think) 2 days now, and I love it. Its a real good system for creating stuff. The amount of people should be able to be limited to a certain amount (to prevent people getting kicked for no reason) or be able to get re-invited for a clone. I have seen some stories where there were 4 people needed and 8 people asked to get in. Maybe the reject button has some standard explanations why you were rejected (not in line with character, party full, etc. etc.). This makes it much simpeler to know why you were rejected.
"options" isn't the right word, since I obviously can choose to make a game with those yet. But none of the "Kickstarter" worlds after In Nomine show up on the page.
I know it's belated. I've been a bit busy for the last 24 hours, but congrats Storium team! Very excited about this project!

@Storium - I noticed that when I start a new game, I have options for all of the worlds up to In Nomine, with that one being locked and still waiting for $150,000.00 to be unlocked. None of the other Unlockables after $150,000.00 are showing up on the website. Were these not going to be added on the Storium site yet or did you guys get lazy during the last three or four days of the Kickstarter campaign? :P

@A.F. - If you aren't telling them that you are a 50yo disabled guy, they can't be using that as a reason to decline playing with you. One problem I have noticed is that open invitation games get *tons* of people who submit characters. If the story is only designed for 5 players and 100 players submit characters, it's very possible they just used first-come-first-served to pick who gets to play. I have a game that I am Narrating right now, called Friendly Skies. I was going to open it up for open invitation at Chapter 2 start, but I can just send you an invite directly, if you'd like to get into it. Feel free to look up the game and see if you think you might be interested.
Doh! I finally took the time to read the instructions in the pledge reward description. I know how to get beta access now. Silly me. :)
Many thanks in advance for your help.
I would like to see a "bookmark" feature to games that haven't started yet. I would hate to lose track of games I'm interested in joining.

I had an idea. You know how when you have to refresh the page if someone makes a move before you can? It might be a good idea to have a refresh button right there to push, so one doesn't have to click the one at the top of the page. Just a thought for ease of convenience.

I hadn't heard firmly until just then from Stephen none of the stretch goal worlds would be available until public launch. One or two of the earlier to commit to your project might have had the time to complete their work and had already turned their finished world materials in to you. Just making sure to avoid duplicating efforts. :)

Writers being the busy little bees they are, I wouldn't be surprised if at least some of the others were in similar situations. You might want to consider polling them and finding out which ones will be available sooner and which later, so you can come out with a more comprehensive/realistic schedule.
Although 111'666 would be the pinnacle of awesome, unrealistic as it would have been to hope for so many backers.

@Usurper King: Just think of it as being "666" with a "7" stuck in the middle. So you get both the number of the beast AND one of the numbers associated with God, too. It's like an In Nomine twofer. :)
I'm still annoyed that we were ten backers away from having 6'666...

I have an idea that may help, I don't know if anyone mentioned this or not. A player can only play three cards per scene, however, because sometimes a player may only play one card at a time then have hours or even days between moves, he may lose track of how many cards he already played. If he makes plans for a move, and he thinks he has two cards, and can't overcome a challenge because of it, he gets screwed. Maybe have a counter somewhere that can indicate how many cards he has left to play per scene, and as he uses cards, the number will change. This way he can quickly look at the number of cards and make a move based off of that rather than trying to figure out how many cards he's used by looking at past movements.

I'm very happy to find this! I'm a long time player of the today fairly unknown games known as MUSHes (Multi-User Shared Hallucination). I see Storium a spiritual successor to that genre of games. In a MUSH you write stories within a setting and it is all about character building and writing good scenes. There are (still) MUSHes for a lot of genres out there, but they are not as accessible for new users as Storium appears to be. I think you have found a very nice way to bring online storytelling out to new people. Thank you.

Also, I'm glad to hear that you're planning on doing some stretch goals for original or licensed artwork. I agree that having a built-in library of artwork would make Storium *far* more useful. Without face-to-face interaction, artwork is the only way we can "accent" our writing.
